column11: Review Text
Very expensive to see 4 dolphins, a waste of time and money, I do not advise wasting time on this long excursion, which is soporific
Great trip with eagle eye. Well run offered breakfast and snacks and we saw whales! The crew were really organised and motivated. Good boat company to go with not as crowded as other boats we saw.

column8: No whales, far too many boats chasing anything with a fin.
column11: No whales, far too many boats chasing anything with a fin. I felt uncomfortable with it all and it was clear the dolphins were not enjoying the experience. With that many boats out there no whale will stick around, most certainly with a calf. Crew were good and professional. Sri Lankan's as always are hospitable as a people and lovely. An unsustainable industry.
Unlikely to see whales unfortunately. Too many operators and too commercial. There hasnt been a blue whale sighting for months. We didnt see any on our trip.

column8: WONDERFUL ADVICE TO EVERYONE TO SEE THIS SHOW
column11: Good morning dear readers, First of all I have to thank so much the captain of the boat for what he did for me and my wife and all the staff present of the really lovely people ... There was everything eat drink and a friendliness 'never seen .. At first you could not find whales or dolphins but then with their experience they took us to a place where at first we saw dolphins passing very close to the boat ... and then those big impressive whales, it looked like a movie ... these big whales that we filmed for about 15 20 minutes for what they did ,,,, nice to try . It remains for me to thank you again on behalf of myself and my wife for everything See you soon Tziano and Dilki
3 hours on a brilliant boat that vibrates everywhere to see nothing except a school of little dolphin that tried to avoid the x boats crowded with tourists.

Unfortunately, it is true that the sighting can not be guaranteed but in any case whenever there was a hint of a possible whale sighting on the spot, 6/7 boats gathered which already made sighting impossible. I think it is worth spending a little more but make the trip with a small boat with someone more experienced and less effect ‚Äúsightseeing‚Äù....

column8: Managing expectations on Mirissa Whale Whatching
column11: This tour was on our plans since the beggining, we read that Mirissa was so rich in marine life and that delight us. Just for context,  we're from Portugal and have already seen whales in our country. We were expecting a similar experience and maybe that is the problem ... This review is just to manage expectations and for you to know what to expect from this tour or any other whale whatching tour in Mirissa (private or in group). They don't know were the whales are, there is no tracking system. They talk to the fishermen and the boat will leave for the tour case the fishermen spotted whales or not. In our case, they didn't spot any whales so they took us to the place in the sea where they were normally spotted. They found one fin whale and the next 1h30/2h was spent following that whale around that came up to breath every 10 minutes.... and that's it. The whale stays up for like 3 seconds so if you are lucky and looking at the right spot at the right time then you could see a whale for 3 seconds. Every time the whale came up they said that the next time would be the Last and after we would move to another spot to look for more. They said that sentence at least five times... The group tours and the private boats are all in the same place and they just follow each other. So, yes we did spot one whale and two sea turtles. If that is good enough for you then you should definately come. The tour staff is very nice, they will give you a sandwich,  slice of cake and some fruit (for included breakfast and snacks). We left the harbour around 6h50 and arrived around 9h45.

Chances of seeing a whale are less but you definitely get to see dolphins. But sea sickness is a major issue. If you have motion sickness, then avoid this trip. The boats go around the same area. The only difference between the different boats is what and how they serve the snacks. So choose a non exorbitant one.

It was not worth it. We didn't see any whales, just dolphins. Many companies offer the same service. When one ship spots the dolphins, it starts to rush towards them, followed by all the others. the poor animals get scared away in this way, and you yourself have a bad feeling about all this approach.

I found it overhyped and not worth the effort. There are much better places in the world to see dolphins which are less crowded with viewing boats. And to be clear, only the top of the whale‚Äôs back spouting water can be seen. It‚Äôs nice to see, but I would not necessarily recommend that everyone should make the effort.

Highly disappointing and it's a disturb for the marine life. . I had read lot of reviews and watched YT videos on whale watching. But it was a myth.  . I must say it was totally a waste of money and ur precious time. We had to leave our room early morning at 5 30 and my toddlers were so excited to spot whales. Upon reaching the harbour u would be given breakfast,  coffee , antisickness tablets and the ships would start around 7 am and come back to harbour by 10: 30am.    But we couldn't spot even a single whale on the day we went. They chased few dolphins which was so annoying. So if u are a person with kids and family and who has sea sickness  i would definitely not recommend this.

We took a whale-watching tour on a speedboat, we were pleased. Five-person boat, three of us. The team is very fast, we were always one of the first to come when the marine life showed up. Saw a lot of dolphins, grinds and two Finnish whales. Spent four hours in comfort. We were even given sedation pills and a fruity breakfast.
Safe your time and money! Don‚Äôt do it. It was like a hunt. Very weird experience‚Ä¶ 7-8 big boats were chasing one whale that was spotted in the water. Felt bad about it

Very disturbing experience. Besides the fact that we didn‚Äôt see any whale (not even from far), it‚Äôs more like a hunt. As soon as some dolphins were in sight, dozens of motor boats speeded to them and surrounded them. A smaller boat even drove through. It‚Äôs probably big business for people in Mirissa, but don‚Äôt support it.

My experience with whale watching in Mirissa was a mix of excitement and slight disappointment. We embarked on the tour at 6:30 am, full of anticipation for spotting majestic whales and playful dolphins. The boat ride itself was enjoyable, with knowledgeable guides providing insights into the marine ecosystem and pointing out various sea creatures along the way. Although we were fortunate enough to see several dolphins, the sighting of whales was not as clear as I had hoped. It's possible that they were a bit shy or not as active on the day of my visit. Despite this, the experience of being out on the open ocean and witnessing these creatures in their natural habitat was still captivating. In conclusion, while my whale watching experience in Mirissa didn't meet all of my expectations, I still enjoyed the adventure and would recommend it to others,

We were disappointed. We saw some small whales from far away (mainly their blowouts), but impossible to catch them on a picture or even come close. Saw a few small dolphins, that was nice. The boat was ok. We were served a cup of coffee, anti-sickness pills and a tasty breakfast. Nobody offered a life vest, and we didn‚Äôt ask for it. We had to leave our hotel in Beruwela at 5 am, start of tour at 7:30 am, and spent 130‚Ç¨ p.p. including transport in a minibus. Back around 13:30h. Quite expensive for what we saw. The crew did their job and of course nobody knows where the whales are and whether they‚Äôre up for jumping. But we‚Äôve had better experiences in other parts of the world. We would not recommend it in Mirissa. Value for money is a mismatch.

Less than 50% chance of seeing a whale and then it‚Äôs like whacky races as all the tourist boats race to see it. 8 boats to 1 mink whale. Be careful,who you book with. We had a coach load of old tourists who just ran over the small boat to get the best picture with no consideration. A lot of money for an unpleasant experience.

We couldn‚Äôt spot any whales, one whale spotted was too far and hardly saw any part of its body except its fin so it could be anything like a dolphin also. Nothing to blame the crew it‚Äôs nature. But I suppose there are parts of the world where the whales population is really high so the chance of spotting one would be easy. But in Mirissa it was like looking for a needle in a hay stack. For me it was a disappointment as I planned my Sri Lanka trip in February as I heard it was the best time to watch whales. May be it was my bad luck. Try it if you would enjoy the ride to the sea. I am a vegtarian the sandwich provided was either sausage or egg. Tip - make sure you were quick dry clothes as you might get splashed sometimes.

Nothing to be seen and extremely expensive‚Ä¶ we saw some dolphins and a turtle, but no whales to be spotted. The 98% chance is totally overestimated. Of course there‚Äôs a part of luck, but for the money paid you‚Äôre at least want to know the real chances

Went on an organised boat trip on Eagle Eye. Could not fault the boat, staff where lovely food supplied. Unfortunately for us the whales were not playing that day but we did manage to see a lot of dolphins. Recommend the trip and we will be trying again hopefully with better luck next time. Will definitely be going with Eagle Eye again.
Expensive and not worth the money. As hard as the crew tried they could not find a whale, not really their falut but don‚Äôt waste you‚Äôre money. Or there again you might be lucky.

Proper sh*t, over hyped and waste of the most expensive boat ride of my life- 100usd If it were a reasonable price I‚Äôd have left a good review as a nice boat ride at least. Still the missus wanted to do and I must comply I know it‚Äôs luck of the draw, but for me we didn‚Äôt really see much plus the boat was full of obnoxious Russians who wouldn‚Äôt sit down or shut up when the crew were talking.

It was one of the worst days of my life! No whale, extremely choppy water, no life jackets given. When I had put this up on my Instagram many ppl DMd that similar things had happened with them so it wasn‚Äôt a one off experience of mine. Pls do not waste your time at all in doing this

After a late-night wake-up call and eight hours of navigation on very uncomfortable seats, you will find yourself with dozens and dozens of boats chasing some poor whales which, if you are lucky, you will see from afar and only a few puffs and tails. Highly polluting activity (an unbearable smell of diesel). If you love the planet (but also your butt and your wallet), DON'T DO IT!

We went with Dhanushka tours. Positives: they provide food at the beginning (don't eat if you are prone to seasickness), anti-puke medicine and puke bags. Negatives: No shelter if it rains while at sea. The guide's voice doesn't reach the back. We couldn't see any whales... while they promise 96% chances of whale sighting, on the boat they change it to 50%! Tip: Carry wind cheaters and rain coats

We booked our trip a day before with Kumara whale Watching.  The boat, crew and hospitality were excellent.  However, the actual experience of seeing whales was disappointing.  There were too many boats racing to see the creatures probablyscaring them away. When something was spotted everyone stood up and those with kids or elderly were unable to see anything. When we did get a glimpse of something in the sea it  was too far to discern what it was. We just had to take the word of the guide that it was a whale. We spent nearly 4 hours and it was too boring for everyone, one not just the families.  When the guide announced that we were going back , there was a loud cheer. I think it is too expensive ( 70$ per person) and utter waste of time, unless you like just a ride on the boat....wished we stayed at our beachside hotel.

The boat was definitely the nicest one in the port, and the crew very enthousiastic and kind. We saw several whales and dolphins, and they never went too close to the animals to disturb them, as opposed to all the other ships in the area. They even offered complementary sandwiches and water, and as much water melon as one could eat. Before departing, we were also offered pills against sea sickness, but we declined these. We had a great time  and would definitely recommend this!

Venture for this activity only if you don‚Äôt have sea sickness.Also it‚Äôs pretty steep to not see whales.Indulge in this activity in the right season December to mid March and when the sea isn‚Äôt rough.Although our company tried a lot ,we couldn‚Äôt spot a whale .They provide packed breakfast and fresh fruits and nausea bags too.

We used Danushka Tours for whale watching. Inspite of the many reviews, we thought it was a good experience. The guides try hard to make sure the group sees some whales, this sometimes needs them to go further out to the sea and that is why it may take longer hours. If you get sea sick then factor this in or sit in the lower part of the ship, otherwise it's nice to enjoy the time at sea and see the beautiful colours of the ocean, we even saw a rainbow! We had 2 children with us both were sea sick and the staff helped us throughout with good advice on how to make it easier for them. There was no mess and all sea sick passengers had sea sickness bags, all in all its fine and you do get to see whales and dophins at the end of it.

We set out full of great expectations, but also appreciating that whales and dolphins are wild.  We left prompt at 7am and paid 22,000lkr each.  We were back in the harbour before 11am.  We received one dry bun with an omelette thing in it and one bottle of water.  We saw 4-5 dolphins for about two minutes and that was the extent of our trip.  I felt that the crew knew that the whales weren't near so just did the minimum to make the trip.  Just didn't feel it was worth over ¬£200 for the pleasure.
Awesome experience. must visit if you're in Down south Sri Lanka. the whole team was knowledgeable and knew exactly where we need to go. definitely coming back thushara

Had an early morning whale watching trip in Mirissa. Had an enjoyable boat ride into the ocean and managed to spot a lot of dolphins. We were lucky enough to spot a whale. In our boat the staff were quite friendly and provided us with breakfast and water. Carry a pair of hat and sunglasses to avoid the glaring sun. If you are someone who gets seasick, I suggest you carry a sick bag or take necessary pills prior to manage the unavoidable seasickness.

Met with hassle at the port. Ticket sales people trying to rip you off starting at 50 USD pp plus local taxes. Then said OK I'll give you a good price. The boats are old and don't look good. We didn't bother and came back to our hotel. Talking to other guests all had a similar experience. Don't waste your time and let them rip you off.

This is not an observation, this is a hunt. We turned around an Orque during 2h hours with 10 boats who make noize and polution around us. Just an advice, don't wast time and money to feed this horrible business. This is not good for animals, not good for nature and mostly not good you.
We had a really amazing experience .... we will never forget this morning. We have seen whales several times. Really amazing. Thank you so much for serving us too.

We did see Fin whales and dolphins,  however only partial sightings where they just break the surface with their backs. We didn't see the whole of them at any stage. I am completely aware that they are in their natural habitat and not performing at Sea World (thankfully). However, the cost was expensive at $50 each. I can only compare it to my other 1 experience where in the Caribbean we did a sunset dolphin cruise and they were swimming alongside and leaping out of the water alongside the boat, which was awe inspiring. I guess my negative feedback is caused by the fact that the boat staff were whooping and trying to make out that we had had an amazing experience and had seen everything we could have wished for. I might feel more positive if they had been a bit more realistic about the experience we'd had. Finally, I was hoping to see some of the Blue Whale population which they bragged are so numerous, however we didn't even look for any. As soon as they ticked the box with partial sightings of fin whales and dolphins, we headed back to shore. Finally (sorry to go on), there was virtually zero information about the whales and dolphins generally

Overall experience was amazing. Saw multiple dolphins and a blue whale a couple of times. The captain was excellent- he tried his best to spot the whale and made sure we spotted the whale 3 times. Loved the service on board- the staff was super helpful. Totally recommend the experience.
What a amazing experiment in our Sri Lankan tour. We could see the biggest 3 Whales and many more Dolphins are jumping on the Sea.

We were told it was guaranteed that we will see a whale but after 3 hours and seasick. We didn‚Äôt see anything! Apparently that was the first time in 6 years that no whale was seen. We were so disappointed... all in all we spent at least 5 hours going there and back. Don‚Äôt rely on the Food provided, is was very basic and dry. They did give you a lot of sick bags as a lot of people were seasick üòÖüòÖ

GUYS please check the weather forecast before booking this whale watching expedition, Sadly we did not, it is expected that you are gonna be super excited to see the whales but trust me you are in for one hell of a ride if the seas are rough, that‚Äôs exactly what happened to us, 2 hours of sailing into the ocean , all of us throwing up, people getting sick and the biggest disappointment is that we saw 1 whale for like 5 seconds , what a waste of money time and energy , the tour operators will try their best to sell the tickets to you at your resort or the jetty but don‚Äôt be fooled by this. Please make sure the weather holds up, I.e not too strong winds . Or else u will surely be left disappointed .
Great time. great experience with my wife thay  help us properly.and their different kind of whales .thank you guys ....
Everythinf was very good they gave us fruit and they were very professional searchinf the whales excursion is perfect for familya and friends

It was one of the worst tourist experiences that I have ever had in my life. Whale watching should be banned is absurd. Every time a whale is sighted, with around twenty full-engine boats chase the poor animal that emerges from the water to take oxygen. If you love animals, you shouldn't do this absurd practice.

Nice boat with nice crew. Breakfast sandwiches, coffee and tea and water. We saw some dolfins and later at least 10 blue whales. Soms boats come to close or chase them. But this boat likes to do it as if should. Were just 3 hours out, close to the shore.

Ticket was USD50 dollars each and on the back of the ticket it says the trip will be 2-6 hours.  I found on the internet beforehand that it would be 3-5 hours.  We were out for no more than 1.5 hours so feel short-changed.  Almost seems that the tour operators just want to off-load you once you've had a sighting. Yes we did see blue whales a couple of times (I think but there was no commentary to confirm) but the whales were quite far away and lots of boats chasing them.

Nature at its best! We saw 2 male sperm whales and a school of dolphins. Staff are very knowledgeable and fully informed us of various marine life both mammals and birds. A few folk got sea sick (me included) but crew dealt with this discreetly and were just brilliant. Can‚Äôt recommend enough.

We were out at sea a total 6 hours. Saw a few spinner dolphins - briefly, and a blue whale fleetingly, on the way back to port. All depends on your luck what you get to see on the day you go out. The boat bounces up a lot, even in a gentle swell, and everyone gets thoroughly wet with the splashes and spray that continuously shower on you. If you do not mind all these, this activity can be done once, You never know how lucky you might get. Was a bit disappointed how pathetic the toilets on the boat were, with one having no toilet seat and flush in both toilets not working. Also, there are half a dozen or more of these boats out there at the same time and when a whale is sighted, they all zero in on it very close, which surely must be highly stressful for these magnificent mammals

This is my second time to see whales in Sri Lanka but with over 14 boats at the same location difficult to see whales and they do not stay on surface long as they are case by the boats. maybe better on low season!

Have to board the boats early in the morning at Mirissa harbour. All boats will go out together to spot the whales. USD50 per person for bigger boats ride, can carry up to 40 people type of boat. Serve you hot beverages, buns, seasick pills onboard. Once out from shore not far all boats will haul and the waiting game begins. Once any sight of the whale, all boats will just rush there in order for you to get a nice photo but is not easy. The boat noise actually scare of the whales and they submerge.If you had seen a whale elsewhere forget about this.
Crew friendly, went out of their way (with 15 other boats) to find a Blue whale for us. Problem, incredibly slow returning back to port, & slow leaving port.
Better to go for it in December-January during their migration. We were lucky to see tales and be close enough.
The service was perfect ( breakfast, pineapple juice, Mango jus and fresh towel). We see some whales, the last is the best ! I recommend this company. Thanks a lot.

While we were in Sri Lanka our main priory was to go whale watching. We did a lot of research to make sure we were going with the right company to give us the best experience. And boy Whale watching club did NOT disappoint. We saw sperm whale, dolphins and, the highlight of our trip, four sightings of a blue whale. Manoj and his team were extremely knowledgeable and respectful of these incredible creatures and this allowed us to pretty much always be the first and closest boat to a sighting, out of many boats (within a respectful and safe distance of course.) It is an early start and there is a bit of waiting around to start but they give you breakfast and feed you delicious fruit and king coconuts throughout the trip. For 7,500 rupees ($40) you shouldn‚Äôt go with anyone else but whale watching club to see whales.
Very bad experience. We see only water bubbles in a journey of 5 hours.  Very bad experience with this horrible trip.
Don't go on low season unless you want to puke and waste your money to see the whale for less than 10 second. The tide is quite rough and unless you have a very strong stomach, you might "enjoy" it.
Excellent experience. Very professional service and we had up close and personal experience with lots of whales

We paid 6500 LKR for one ticket for the boat which will travel approximately 1.5 hour from sea shore. Wait for whale watch in different locations on the sea. We could see only 3 whales out of which only one was seen nicely for 3 seconds. There were 70 people on board and nearly 50 of us got tired after vomiting due to sea sickness and bumpy  ride of boat. They do give you tablet for Vomit control and a plastic carry bag if you vomit. You do get small breakfast and water bottle and fruits on your way in the boat. You need to negotiate on the price as some people paid 9000 LKR for same boat for whale watching. I don‚Äôt recommend it as there are lot of circumstances like weather and your luck in which you do or don‚Äôt see whales.

Although we knew the journey would be rough we really wanted to see some whales. Wow we underestimated how rough it would be! The journey was terrifying and very rough. We had taken sea sickness tablets for a couple of days beforehand as we‚Äôd got some tablets in the UK but I was still nearly sick and so many people were sick. After about 2 hours there was 1 whale all 4 boats followed. We saw it spout water and break out of the water a few times and properly came out once. Then the rains came and we all got completely soaked to the bone. The driver asked if we wanted to head back and we all said yes. The journey back was more terrifying in the rain. Nearly 4 hours it took for a few glimpses of a whale. Not worth it at all I wish we hadn‚Äôt gone!

the Whale watching trip was brill again the crew could not do enough they kept  everybody informed all the trip with as much information they could and we did see Whales numerous times the trip lasted 10hrs well worth it

Timing: - you get picked around 5:30am depending on your location. - boat moves 7am sharp or few mins earlier Boat: - capacity of approx 150 people - narrow seats and poor safety - you get to wear life jacket - two bathrooms available on lower deck Crew: - very friendly and casual - zero safety instructions Price: - $51 adults, 9000 rupees - $ 31 kids, 5500 rupees Sea sickness pills not offered on our boat. Many people vomited. Sea was rough on that day and was very tiring experience. Actual magical scene of seeing whales and dolphins took no more thank 5mins. You get to spend around 3-4 hrs for that trip. In my opinion it‚Äôs is not worth it at all. Skip it if you can. Actual boat is different than the one on the ticket. The real one is much more outdated.

Our first time whale watching in Mirrisa so a new experience. The sea was pretty bumpy and lots of people got sick. If you're prone to sea sickness then don't do this tour. We saw multiple whales from afar so it was nice that we didn't seem to be disturbing the animals. According to the boat crew there were blue whales and sperm whales there at the time. We saw at least 3 seperate whales breach the water with their tales before diving. We asked a crew member if they used sonar to find the Whales and he said no. Hopefully this is true. Overall a great experience, would definitely do again.

I got to Mirrisa about 11 o'clock, although I read up not to go out in midday as the waters are to rough I really wanted to see a blue whale as I travelled all the way to sri lanka from UK. After asking around the whole of Mirrisa I finally found someone crazy enough to take me out. I managed to hire a boat for about 20 people for myself for about ¬£130. Right from the off the waves was strong looking like they was either gona snap the boat in half or come over the top of the boat. I did manage to see 1 killer whale, 1 back of a blue whale and loads of flying fish. It was the flying fish that stopped me from breaking into tears from fear of the waves coming into the boat, I was actually soaked from the water that was coming into the boat. The captain told me when I got off im so lucky. I was scared as it was but when the captain started scratching his head like we was lost an we couldnt see any land as we travelled out for about 2 hours I was getting worried. The captain then let a 16 year old lad take over so he could look for the way back. I actually thought I was going to die with getting lost an the horrible waves. Couldnt see another boat or land in site ya start to panic on a tiny boat in crazy waves.

What an amazing morning! Make sure to choose a reputable tour operator as some boats appeared to be close to capsizing! Unless you know that you need it, don‚Äôt take the meds offered agains seasickness - it knocked us, and others, out on the way back and we slept for four hours after!

hello,I'm from Srilanka,this is my first experience of whale watching with UK friends, we went there at 6.00 am,we started our journey at 6.30 am,they supplied us,goos condition boat, life jackets,and delicious breakfast,we saw a very big turtle,we went far as we cannot see the land, bit long journey but very  interesting,dolphins were everywhere,yes its really amazing,we saw 3 whales coming up over the the sea level,time was about 11.40 am,we had some videos,photos,anyone can have good opportunity to capture nice photos,any how we ride our boat back to the land,and time was 12.15 pm, and we finished the amazing sea journey,We hope to do whale watching again,

We had to leave quite early in the morning as we were based out of Bentota but the 4AM departure was totally worth it. The boats vary a lot in terms of upkeep and I would recommend that you check with a local as to how to go about getting a decent boat. The breakfast offered is a basic omelette bun with coffee and biscuits. They also offer some fruit at the end of the tour. The boats generally head out in a bunch and then spread out in an area where there is a higher possibility of spotting the whales. They also rely on phone calls from local fishermen and other boats to zone the area. We were quite lucky to spot not one but several of these huge beasts. It was a sight. We also got to see Dolphins, Flying Fish, Turtles, Jelly Fish while on the tour. I am not too sure about how much the noise of these 31 whale watching tours and numerous speed boats zipping around trying to get close to the whales affects them and not sure how long this will continue to operate. There were smaller boats which were getting irresponsibly close to the whales. Overall a fantastic experience to spot one of the rarest animals in the world.

We boarded the ship run by the Sri Lanka Navy, it was a wonderful experience,  firstly, we felt very safe, all safety regulations were adhered to, there was no overcrowding etc. When we did see the whales, it was truly a special experience. We saw many, many Orca therefore there were no blue whales around.

Thank you Geeth and crew for an awesome morning and great photo opportunities with he Blue Whales you found for us! Absolutely loved the trip, breakfast included, and Geeth is very knowledgeable about the Blue Whales üòä

the beautiful whales aside, you need to keep in mind you'll spend nearly 2 uneventful hours going in one direction. So be prepped for that. Also do your research, the costs for these rides fluctuate between 5000-10000 lkr per person.

I have never been on a Whale watching experience and this was my first time and it was truly incredible and amazing. It is an absolute please to watch this giant mammal play around and when they go back in the water their big giant tales is a pleasure to watch. Nothing can beat this.

We went whale watching with Jagabay tours. I must say they‚Äôre a great team. The boat was clean, the breakfast offered was great too. They offered sickness pills to people too, thoughtful! We spotted shoals of dolphins 3,4 times. Some whales and flying fishes. They didn‚Äôt approach the animal very close so they didnt harm or scare it. They made sure we see the fishes to our contentment. I can recommend this tour compant to anyone.

As there are many different boats available, the only common rating I can give is that once a whale is seen, approximately 30 boats run toward the animal and are almost hunting the poor animal. Also many boats release oil and fuel into the ocean and plastic being thrown into the ocean. As I have done already few whale watching tours, this one was definetly the poorest one. The price of 50$ is absolutely over expensive for this tour. Sorry to be that honest !
A very good tour with great hospitality and making sure that you actually see whales and dolphins to your hearts content. Raja and whales really takes care of its visitors and clients

it didn't take long to find dolphins...probably 20-30 of them speeding through the waves and jumping out of the water.  Shortly after we found a whale...breathtaking!  The guides were great - knowledgable, friendly.  One even took photos for me...better than I would have ever gotten!  Worth the time for sure!

Bought tickets from our hotel ( 9000 rps Government said the hotel manager?!?) to this brilliant safari. The boat seemed almost brand new. Omelettsandwich, some fruits, tea/coffee and juice was served during the safari. Best of all, two blue whales, a lot of dolphins and some flying fishes. Absolutely smashing day. Trip started 7:00 am back in Mirissa at 10

Unlike other whale watching trips I've been on there was no entertainment or bar on the boat, so for the long hours between sightings there is nothing to do or see. There's not even a sun deck. But unlike other trips they did keep going until we found a blue whale. In all we were out for seven and a half hours as the whale was so far out. Having been out over the guaranteed trip duration (I think 3 hours) we didn't stay long enough once we'd found it but 'rushed' back to port, and the two hours coming back were exceptionally tedious. So if you really want to see a whale go for it. Otherwise don't bother, it's a long trip for just a few minutes of sightings. On the plus side the crew were friendly and the included breakfast (fried egg sandwich, chicken sausages and fruit) was far superior to the packed one from the hotel. And we did come across a large pod of dolphins on the way out to the whale, which was the best dolphin watching I've had.

Having spent 19 magical days in the wonderful Sri Lanka 'Whale Watching' left a very sour taste in our mouths! This is a very expensive disappointment... We left shore at 6:35 and were back ashore less than 2 hours later. We got to see a whale spout over 300 meters away, then see his tail submerge into the sea again. We saw the same whale surface 3 times (all in about 40 minutes) never closer than 200 meters, which is well over 2 football pitch lengths away. I asked the leader was that it? He told me "You were lucky, some days it takes 6 hours to see a whale! Funny, because our TukTuk driver told us he would collect us at 9:30! Everyone around us all expected so much more and felt very cheated. Sri Lanka don‚Äôt rip off your tourists, it is not clever.
Excellent place to see the dolphins and whales. our guests very happy with whale watching trip. they recommend to others.

The have bugged the whales so much we had to go 3 hours out, and saw them from a long way off. Save your 100 bucks unless you like seas sicknesses and a bad sandwich. If you do go take your own food!!!! And you probably won‚Äôt see any whales just 10 old boasts racing to look for a needle in a haystack!! Lots of people being sick so dont take your good shoes!
I feel they love our closeness. Never try to harm us. let us got as much as possible photos. Some times our boats goes closer than we like but still it's safe

There are lots of boats leaving from Mirissa but they all charge the same because the price is controlled by the government. You get picked up early in the morning from your hotel, taken to Mirissa and board your boat. The trip lasts a good few hours and they seem to stay out until you have seen a whale. We saw several whales and dolphins. The boat provided a simple meal which went down well. Greta trip

Me and my 2 friends picked this company from tripadvisor reviews and we were not disappointed. We saw 5 whales and loads of dolphins. The guides were very knowledgable, they made sure everyone on the boat had a good view which meant people were not pushing eachother to get a look. Be warned it is choppy but thats part of the fun of it. My friend was sea sick and the guides were very attentive and kind, they really went above and beyond. Would highly recommend.

Amazing experience. The team on the boat was professional- courteous, caring, and not missing any opportunity to spot the whales. They explained each and every person on board about the whales, help taking pictures, providing break-fast, cold drinks, coconut water, fresh fruits. The best part was that unlike other boats this boat they accomodate only around 35 passengers as committed. So yes they are indeed committed to safety first. Other boats that we could spot we more than full - scary sight. Go for whale watching club and you will not regret the expeience.

7 hours on a boat and we saw a splash of water that was supposed to be a whale. No guarantee you'll see anything but there's a high possibility you'll get sea sick.  Also, the boats are crowded and so loud they'd scare animals miles away.

Me, my husband and daughter went out in the early morning with these guys. We were served hot tea firstly. The boat wasn‚Äôt overcrowded. They got us up close to firstly dolphins and then they followed us in their hundreds. It was amazing. They slowed for us to see the passing gentle giant turtles and then pointed out a breaching whale in the distance, when we just stared in awe. It was amazing. We were then lucky enough to have blue whales come near to us when they stopped the boat. I felt this was reward for respecting them as we did witness another boat chasing after them üò¢. Juicy pineapple, bottles of water and watermelon was served on the way back. They even let my daughter steer the boat which she loved. I‚Äôd definitely recommend you go with these friendly, respectful guys.

It was a very nice experience. I felt it similar to the saffari I did in Africa, in a way that you are looking for this beautiful creatures, but there is no guarantee you will meet them. Well, we did :-). These guys are very good, they know how to find the whales. It turns out the blue whales are not showing their whole body. They stay under the water until they have to take a breath. Then they go up, you see the fountain, part of the whale's back, finally the tale and it goes down the water for another 10-15 min. And this you see from a distance, may be 100-200m or even more. Similar to the saffari, we were saling together with other boats and even those small motor boats, which I found a bit aggressive and noisy. We were staying with motor turned off and then they somehow knew the whale will show, then they were switching the motor on, got closer and we were enjoying the view. The boat itself wasn't very luxury, but still it was OK. And there were tea, coffee, water, fruits.

Having been whale watching twice before I have to say this was the most overpriced and commercial site I've been to. We were on the boat by 6 and left at 7. The upper deck was full although people arrived after us and went upstairs. Decided we felt pressure from Chinese group for our seats so we went on deck only to be completely surrounded by very loud Chinese group. Once at the site as soon as a whale spout was seen all the boats...and there were about 20, all rushed over and completely swamped the whale(s). A lot were spewing diesel fumes and if I were a whale I would surface as little as possible. Caught a glimpse of 4 whale spouts / backs. Felt guilty about being part of this aggressive act. At $50 a head it was pricey and then boat hands came round with a tip box... a lot of pressure after paying a lot. "You not happy, dont pay, you happy,pay" but they didn't leave until Chinese gave more money... we didn't. $50 was more than enough for the experience thanks! It needs much better control.

I‚Äôll preface this review by stating this was our experience only.  We arrived early and purchased our tickets. This was a seamless experience. We were told that the government had recently taken over the whale watching excursions and all tickets, regardless of the boat, were $50 US. We purchased our tickets and sat on the boat for about 45 minutes before taking off.  About five minutes after taking off there was some excitement from the captain which turned out to be a blue whale. We were told we were very lucky because normally the captain would have to travel 15 to 20 km out to sea before seeing a whale.  This is all well and good if by ‚Äòsee‚Äô you mean nothing more than a dorsal fin emerging every few minutes and disappearing just as quickly.  We followed the whale for a while and the captain did try to ensure people on both sides of the boat had a look, but don‚Äôt expect to see through the masses of people when you see something on the other side of the boat. What‚Äôs more, we were told that government policy mandates that once you ‚Äòsee‚Äô a whale you must come back to shore. Our entire trip lasted no more than an hour. If you are expecting to see whales jumping out of the water or a tail emerge, beware that this is not always likely. Very expensive for what we saw.

Save your money and go elsewhere, we went to mirissa to go on a whale watching tour with mahindrasiri , on arrival told that the prices had risen by 30% due some government tax or some such nonsense,  told to expect 5-6 hr trip which turned out to be 2hrs, we did see a few whales but from a long distance and when a whale was spotted the many boats gave chase making the poor whales dive for a bit of peace,, no information from the boat organisers whatsoever ,poor breakfast, nothing to recommend, should have been one of the best days of our holiday but came away feeling a bit ripped off and sorry for the whales. Don,t waste your money there are plenty of better things to do in srilanka.

We got up at 04.30 to travel here so i was hoping that it would be worth it and it was.  We left the harbour around 7 in the morning and boat sailed for a good hour before we sighted the first spout.  It turns out we had a really good day.  We had stumbled among a group (is it a school?) of Blue Whales!! Even the staff on the boat were excited.  We got close to them until they would then dive and the crew would, excitingly, be shouting "tail, Tail" and then they would be gone for 10 minutes.  Really was amazing to see these great creatures.  Apparently, the last 3 days people had not been so fortunate.  The sea was also meant to be calm when we went but these boats do tend to go very fast and there were a few people that needed sick bags. Breakfast was provided (although they dont seem to cater for vegetarians.  so if vegan or gluten free then forget it).  It was well organised and we felt very safe.  They would only allow one side to stand at any given time for safety and allowing others to see the whales.  Fantastic.

One of the main reasons why hordes of tourists invade Mirissa every year  during the high peak season is to join one of the numerous whale watching tours which are run by local companies. In my case that was the main reason why I have opted Mirissa as a destination for my vacation. Unfortunately the day trip I joined was very disappointing. I woke up at ungodly hours just to be on time at the pier. All in all the other participants and I have spent seven and a half hours on the ship basically for nothing. In this wide span of time we could spot three whales only and for a few seconds. What's more they were very far away from us. As much as I have a very good camera, the quality of the snaps I took was really poor due to the distance between me and the mammals. I have no priblems saying that joining this trip has been a waste of money. While strolling in Mirissa forget the beautiful pictures of the whales you can see here and there. These captures are on display only to encourage you to sign up for a day tour. If you really want to join a tour, since it is basically a waste of money for the above mentioned reasons, I would suggest choosing the cheapest you can find. Maybe you can enjoy it and see whales close to you but the possibilities this will happen are very slim. For the record this tour is also called whale and dolphin watching tour. Needless of me to say I couldn't even see one dolphin.

A lot has been said about not doing it,, However, I beg to differ. If you havent been to any such tour, do take it. The tour starts early morning and before you realise you are in the middle of a huge ocean with sun setting it.. its peaceful and serene.. the trip is well managed. You are served light snacks, fruits, coffee and cake.. ample enough to call it a treat on a ship!! For those who are frightened of sea sickness, one tab(also available onboard) is enough to take care of it! the journey is about 4-6 hours in all but an experience in itself. Why should you do it? and now the main highlights... we did manage to spot many whales and few dolphins from quite close! Though the entire view lasts for only seconds, but if you are okay to count the entire experience in totoality, its worth it! Why you should not do it? If watching whales and doplhins is the only focus for the cruise, then skip it! you will get a way better view of atleast dolphins in those sea parks!!
Mirrisa in srilanka is the best place to see whale during december time. Cost per pex is US$ 35, in a double deck boat. Upper dech is preferable.

After a two hour slow boat ride out the the whale (only one) we saw its tale possibly 3 times. We spent 30 minutes chasing this poor whale with 6 other boats to catch a glimpse. Approx 30 people were sea sick and so we could not go to the lower level of the boat due to the smell. If we had our time again we would not do it.

Blue Whales!  largest creature on earth....simply amazing. They are massive, the ones we saw around 25 metres and 150 tonnes. They dive for 10-15 minutres and come up fpr 1-2 minutes again. You can't see the whole creature but never mind - awesome anyway!

We saw Bryde whales and dolphins but there were so many boats chasing them they did not stay around for long.  We were out on a rolling choppy sea for about 5 hours.  Many people were sea sick.  There are others places in the world where the whale watching is regulated and much kinder for the whales.  The crew were all very enthusiastic and nice but it was not a pleasant experience.

We went with Yamuna Whale watch, whose owner is Chamindq. It is a new boat and the crew is enthusiastic and friendly. We saw two blue whales and their baby within the first 45 mins, and than a pod of dolphins. Overall a pleasant experience with breakfast included. This is the only place I know , that you can see blue whales. Though we have seen humpbacks elsewhere, and close up, with better explanations from guides, the excitement of the crew when seeing these big creatures, unique to this area, makes up for the busy boat of people. I strongly suggest you reserve front seats on the top deck.
We did it as kids wanted to do it even it was not the season we opted for it. But we were not disappointed and saw whales in nice numbers. Kids had great fun,

We went on a very small boat, only room for 8 people... Just don't do it. When you come to the ocean and the waves you will be very sad that you made this choose. We became cold, wet and tired. No whales, some dolfines.. but no whales. After 3,5 hours we asked the boat to return to the harbour, cold wet and in no mood for more Whale hunting.. there were no whales near, and the boat man just said.. We should have stayed 30 minuts more in that direction. they were there yesterday (with water coming into your face) and we should see whales (but how come, you didnt bring us there in the first place than? if the whales was there?) Traveling on and talking to locals in nearby town, we were told that they have not seen any whale for a long time, and there were no whales yesterday. So do not go on this trip if you expect whales, use your time and money on something else... If you can accept dolfines, then you might have luck for your money.

Take little heed of the criticisms levelled on this review site. If you have never seen or experienced the thrill of seeing dolphins and whales look no further. AN early start but well worth it. They crew were very accommodating and took great care of their customers. Everyone was provided with wel fitting life jackets. The boat was clean and tidy with ample room to move around. Breakfast was quickly served as we headed out to sea. Within an hour the shout rung out and the boat was surrounded by dolphins who clearly loved swimming alongside the boat. They stayed with us for over 20 minutes.it was an experience not to be forgotten. Before long we were introduced to our first Blue Whale. It,s water spout identifying it,s position. It was truly awesome. They captain took care ar all times manoeuvring the boat to give us all the best sighting whilst being careful not to interfere with the whale' s wellbeing. All in all we were out on the water for 4 hours. We were lucky enough to experience numerous sightings of these huge mammals. It was an absolute privilege to see them in their natural habitat. Take no notice of the critics this is a trip I feel is worth every penny. It fulfilled an ambition and a long standing dream for me. An awesome morning.

Whale watching and plenty spinning dolphins to see but remember this is out to sea which can be a tad rough. We spent 5 hours bouncing up and down in a crammed boat with quite a few that succumbed to sea sickness so beware. That aside an excellent trip with dolphins spotted right at the start and Whales right at the end, in between we mostly bounced up and down looking at the vast blue expanse of water but that‚Äôs what we signed up for and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Early rise required to get out at 07:00 and great bunch of guys looking after us on the trip.

I went on this trip on 2 January 2019 with my husband. Because of the internet cut, we were not 100% aware that there was a rough sea advisory issued by the Meteorological Institute of Sri Lanka. The board at the office said ''a bit rough'' but the sea was crazy on that day. Seriously, it was a very unpleasant experience, when the water was coming in, the boat was almost lying on one side - terrifying. I asked the crew if this is safe anymore, and asked them to check with the captain. They looked scared as well but said nothing to the captain. So me and some other passengers went to the upper deck to speak with him and he totally ignored the fact that the sea was rough and dangerous. 'I've done that 10.000 times, I know it's safe''. So we were in this hell for another 2 hours until finally we turned back to the harbor. The whole trip took 6 hours. We saw (barely) two whales and couple of dolphins. Food was nice, crew was great. Worth it? NOT at all. I understand the Asian standards of safety, I understand that those trips bring the income to the locals but if there is a rough sea advisory, the boats should not go 80km into the open ocean risking people's lives.

It's so polluting. Some 100 ships go into habitat of these animals and spreads so much oil. One can smell oil all over the place. Going to the place itself is bad experience as half of the people in the boat start puking. For the sight of few seconds it's not worth to hamper natural habitat of these animals. And also it's not necessary that all the boats will sight a whale. Go for snorkeling you will see better fishes and turtle and it won't harm them. I regretted going there and so I recommend not to do so to my friends and family. Please think about it it's very harmful for those animals

Sorry,but it is wasting your time and money.To see a whale tail and two turtles I you can on television!The advertising is so incredible,but its only the words and nice photo ( Also the food they provide is awful!The terrible thing is a plastic bottles thrown from ship(You have to organize some waste bin on your ship for garbage,because it‚Äôs look horrible!!!

I pre-booked this trip from the UK without reading the reviews - when I did I agonised about going ahead with the trip and made the wrong call. Firstly it is a long trip - we were told to arrive at 6 am but did not leave until 7.30 am. It was enjoyable watching sleepy Mirissa come awake and the fishing boats getting ready to sail - but an hour and a half wait was too long. The boat was uncomfortable and crowded with noisy Chinese who constantly moved about the boat or were sea sick. If you suffer from sea sickness why go on such a boat? Secondly there lots of overcrowded boats chasing whales. So while we saw 3 blue whales and one humpback and dolphins the whales do not come to the surface often, do not stay long and only do a short breach. Thus I would stick with David Attenborough and leave the whales to migrate in peace in this beautiful ocean. It is a difficult thing to conclude as whale watching is a source of local income and the crew were marvelous I feel that the number of boats needs to be restricted and that the boats should offer to go out and cut the motors and wait and hope to see a whale. We felt so shattered after this experience we went to swim and play in the surf further along the coast just to unwind.

Spending 35USD per person and starting your day at 5.30am to get best sit on upper deck of Boat to watch a single whale spouting water 1000 of meter way and then all boats rushing to that point is just waste of time and money. Better avoid . Spend your quality time on lovely beaches of Mirissa or have a romantic dinner on beach or do surfing but not whale watching. AVOID.

No whales just a few dolphins, it felt like they didn‚Äôt make the offers to find the whale after the dolphins straight back to Mirissa. A real disappointment for the hole family. The stuff was friendly and helpful like all the people in this country.
Whale watching was one of our highlights of our trip in Sri Lanka. We spotted 2 whales during our trip with Geeth. It was amazing!

We went the ride with my family. We enjoyed the tour very much. We spoted 2-3 whales and big number of dolphins on our way. we were given reasonable breakfast which includes sandwiches, buns, cakes and some fruits with water. The service was given by the crew was amazing. I myself was suffering with sea sickness and they helped me alot to overcome it. Will recommend to everybody to come and experience it. P.s- make sure you swallow the pill they give prior to the tour. That will help you to get rid of  the sea sickness

What an excellent trip, the crew were awesome always on the lookout for something and helping people on the boat.  Very impressed with the whole crew and would recommend to anyone wanting to go whale watching.

It should be called whale chasing and tourist torturing. All the boats were chasing one whale when they see a whale but at the end we could not see any one. I would not advice this activity for any one specially with kids.

Well organised trip with plenty of seating and shade on a clean boat. Staff were good in terms of giving out breakfast and water. Breakfast was egg sandwich, two small sausages, a banana and a bit of chocolate cake which was adequate. We saw some dolphins but no whales. Would have liked some verbal presentation about the location, the whales and why they are there. Just some context and education.

Nice experience for us and for the small kids. It was in Dec2018, first you go inside and then you start watching a lot of dolphins jumping around. Then u start looking into tge whales which is a bit difficult to find and we found it but was far from us They offer water and a sandwich as a breakfast It took us around 3 hours to see all

Went with JetLiner Whale Watching at Mirissa,  did not sight Blue Whales and Killer Whales which your operators proclaim loudly. Cost USD 40, very high rate compared to what we pay Aus $35 in Sydney. Avoid Whale Watching tour, waste of money and time at Mirissa.Dolphins were sighted which are quite common in many other part of the world.
Went with group from bangalore. Services provided by MR Prebath and crew. Great team, services excellent and very friendly.
Many people. High prices. Kamikaze Boat drivers. Whales were hunted not watched. Once and not again.

We went with Kumara boat company. We booked thru an agent on Mirissa beach. Paid 9000rps for 4 of us incl pick up and breakfast pack. About 10 to 20 boats leave from Mirissa at around 7am. When anything exciting is spotted, the operators message each other, and before long a fleet of boats encircles the poor creatures. Minimum recommended 100m separation distance is not observed as the boats jostle for position as close as 10m to animals. Imagine you are the poor whale, or a small baby dolphin. The fright of being surrounded by big boats with loud engines, cutting off your escape routes. Chasing you down when you desperately surface to breath, risking being cut up by the propellors. No chance of finding food to eat, as all the fish have been scared away. So you are hungry as well as tired and scared.üò¢ All because some tourists want to get very close to you so they can take photos to show off to their friends! The Sri Lankan government needs to enforce a code to protect the cetaceans. Minimum 100m distance. No encirclement, there must always be open ocean on one side. No chasing after fleeing animals. Until then, all tourists please stay away!

It is like a morning event for the tourists in Mirissa, So many boats from different operators take you to sea for whale watching. Approximate cost per head is Rs.5000 LKR but includes the breakfast and tea. Total time requited about 3 hours, 1hour to go, 1 hr for watching, and 1 hr for return. We have seen 03 whale during this tour but you don't know where the whale will come to surface for breathing. It stays about 40/50 sec before goes down. So, you must be lucky that your boat is close to this surface. It can be taken as a fun that you are out for a  short tour with so many people for sea voyage. But as per our tour operator, there are about 80% chance of watching whale. So can enjoy if your pocket allows ans having spare time.

Not worth  the money we paid Take off from our hotel @4:30am Boat was hot crowded we didn‚Äôt see any wheal Only shark wheal  for 3 mints But not worth the 8 hours trip My advise to u  don‚Äôt waste your time on the boat for a long  trip with no chance to see the wheals
See earlier submission. Strongly recommended to those visiting Galle. We were very lucky to see a Turtle, school of playful Porpoises and many Blue whales

What an absolutely fantastic trip. We would recommending going with Geeth, as we did not hunt the whales like the other boats. We floated and waited for the whales to come near us, and sure enough they did. We seen 4 blues,one very large female, 2 males and a younger one. Really is an experience of a lifetime. Thank you Geeth and team. PS breakfast and the water melon were lovely too.

Was a great experience. We saw much more than we imagined. They also give you enough time to take the experience in. For those who love whales and Dolphins like my daughters,  this is a good place to be in.
Took 6 hours in total. Saw a blue whale and some spinner dolphins. Reasonable information. Was just as migration season starting.

Really enjoyed this trip. We saw so many whales including the magnificent blue whale. The staff were very friendly and offered some great facts about the whales. Be wary if you get sea sick, take some tablets before! I am fine on boats and it does not bother me, but some people were not feeling too great. But it is so worth it to see these incredible whales. My only concern was some smaller boats would go racing over to where a whale was spotted - it seemed very stupid to do as they could cause an injury to the whales. Our boat gave a respectable distance at all times and mentioned these smaller boat companies are a nightmare!

We had a wonderful dolphin and whale watching experience with Manoj and his crew. It is worth every penny! We were picked up at 5.50 and we left the harbor with 8 people on the boat at 6.10 and had a breakfast with on the sea with perfect sunrise. We saw over 200 dolphins and more than 20 whales. During our time on sea we found a turtle that was strangled in a fishing net. The crew was so kind and saved the life of this beautiful turtle. Overal the breakfast was good and we had some snacks, coca cola and delicious fruits. My girlfriend and I would recommend whale watching club to everyone.

The day we were due to go it was raining very heavily. We were hesitant because of the weather but the company was still happy to take the boat out so we went. There was easily 2-3 meter waves the whole time and it didn‚Äôt stop raining. Fortunately it was quite a large boat we were on compared to some others we saw out on the water at the same time. There were many people getting sea sick, the company does offer sea sick tablets though and vomit bags. Despite the weather it was totally worth it! Once we stopped we saw about 10-15 blue and fin whales, they came up so close to us it was incredible! Unfortunately we didn‚Äôt take any photos.. we were scared to bring our cameras up to the top deck because the boat was rocking so much but just to see these animals was amazing! Definitely worth going on - just check the weather forecast, take the sea tablets and make sure you‚Äôre on a good quality boat!

Whale watching is an interesting fun activity in Galle. Sri Lanka is surrounded by ocean which makes it more accessible to observe these huge sea mammals and quite a number of dolphins too. You have to start quite early to the beach to catch a boat. If you have come to Galle for a holiday then most of the Hotels provide a trip to ‚Äòwhale watching‚Äô. Otherwise, you can get into the beach directly and go for it.

Before booking I had read so many poor reviews and had not heard good things about the whale watching in Mirissa. We set off from the marina at 7:30am (slightly late). The waters were quite rough and not the most pleasant boat trip. However, it was worth it! We saw at least 10 blue whales. They came very near to the boat. An absolutely incredible visit. The whole tour lasted 3 hours, breakfast, water and refreshments were served. The workers were so kind to those who fell ill on the boat. I would highly recommend this tour, set off early to ensure you don‚Äôt miss your boat and if you suffer with travel sickness then ensure you pack some travel sickness tablets they will be needed!
The waves are rough at times. Half of the people on board were sick. Only saw a few blue whale backs. Make sure if you go not to pay much.

I saw a lot of bad reviews for this but I‚Äôm not sure what people were expecting. Of course you wouldn‚Äôt see whales jumping out the air doing acrobatics. I‚Äôve never seen a whale before and even seeing it‚Äôs back and tail as it squirted water in the air was amazing. Complaints this is cruel in other reviews. To be frank, if the whales had a problem, they can dive and hold their breath for a long time to get away. The boats never went very close to them either but still had a good view. Also it cost about 40usd which includes breakfast and water. Yes, there were a couple of people who threw up so if this bothers you then don‚Äôt go. To be honest I was more engrossed looking for whales. I also previously gotten sea sick but I had one of the sea sickness tablets they provided and felt absolutely fine.

Even though it was low season the crew managed to spot four whales and two different species, and a lot of dolphins jumping out of the water and this was fantastic! Obviously you won't see the whale jumping, this species don't, you can see the back spine, the tails and the spray. However the experience wasn't totally wonderful: as often happen in this time of the year, because of the monsoons, the ocean was rough which meant that most of the people on the boat got sick. And this was very unpleasant. To seek for the wild animal you must go far from the shore (2/3 hours and back) so if you suffer of seasickness or you can't stand people throwing up just don't go! They provide you with pills against the seasickness but also the give you a sandwich and water!!

It was not that wonderful experience, since we went in August, the sea was a bit rough and you barely can watch the whales. They are far and not that clear.. Most of the people in the tour were vomiting and tired rather than enjoying the whales watching... I don't really recommend it.. We paid around 30USD per person including the hotel pick up for a 3 hours trip not really worth it.

Our boat was supposed to leave at six thirty but they left the hourbor around 7:30. We were the last boat to leave. The sea was very rough and by the time we reached the whale spot it was too late. We barely saw them.

The ever smiling, mischievous dolphins will put on a show while some of the oldest and the largest sea creatures, the humpback and the blue whales, will nonchalantly  glide past you, when you embark on a whale/ dolphin watching excursion off the Southern, Eastern or the West coast of Sri Lanka. The ideal locations for whale watching would be Dondra Point (accessible from Galle, Hikkaduwa and Mirissa) and Trincomalee while the sea off Kalpitiya teems with an abundance of dolphins.

We paid 3500 rupees, picked up at 6.15, 7am boat started. Many people got sick on boat, they provided sea sickness pill before the boat departs. Nothing to see except sitting and seeing the others vomiting, can actually free try again the next day but guess not worth to try since here raining the whole day now. Sad but nothing we can do

I really enjoyed with whale watching Mirissa My hotel locate in unawatuna I went with my husband We are not paid more money I paid only 6500rs(ticket prize) My transport was free.. its arranged by travel agency.. they told me its all around galle area they have free transport..so i suggest to all of you contact with that transport agency and go your trip free They have good drivers with good cars Thank you..

Although my 'boat safari' was supposed to last six hours, the tour ended in about 3 hours. No matter, you'll only catch brief glimpses of whales spouting at a distance - they don't stay on the surface very long.  That plus the constant rocking of the boat makes photography nearly impossible, particularly if you only have a smart phone. Make sure you're not prone to motion sickness as this is not a 'smooth sailing.' A half dozen sight seers succumbed and were hunched over the lower deck chairs, barfing into black plastic bags provided by the crew. If you're REALLY desperate to see a glimpse of a whale, then cough up 6500 rupee for a ticket.

There is a lot of hulaballooo around this experience. The guide the driver everyone asked us to go for this... Even though we read this is not the season, the boat company insisted they came up close to the whales last few days and we were tempted to go. The tickets though were 6500 LKR per person, they gave us a discount as well, so the deal was too good to refuse. At the hindsight, it was a bit of an avoidable experience.. totally it was about 4 hours to go and come back. The trip started out really exciting, braving the rough seas.. but as we went into the seas, eveeryone started to get sea sick, the hosts were handing out water and puke bags as well.. after the few hours, the experience was quite bad with the boat filthy and rocking like crazy... we didnt spot any whales, though came across a whole school of dolphins almost about 100s of them, which was the only exciting part of the journey... They offered breakfast as well, but noone took it as half of them were sea sick and for the rest the boat was rocking so hard to sit and eat... Would recommend this only during the season time and not otherwise.
We saw glimpses of some fins and pumps from the whales. Ridiculous. This was an utter waste of tumultuous 6 hours on a rocky ferry- for nothing. It was hot and many ppl were seasick. Tourturous.

This was another of those trips where we had heard about how great they were and we came away disappointed. Again, not the fault of anyone but it was just bad timing. We spent around five hours cruising on the ocean waves trying to source the whales. It started out lovely, an enjoyable sea breeze and relaxing waves. However after about four hours you could see people getting cranky and frustrated as they had other plans booked and didn‚Äôt know if they would make it back in time. However, eventually, the great giants of the ocean decided to turn up, at least two of them. Well, a mother and baby. As our time was limited, we got to see them breach, and a few seconds later, with a wave of the tail they were gone. And so we returned to shore, happy at least that we had seen something. On the way back, a friendly pod of dolphins decided to show their cheeky faces and put on a bit of a show. Being the intelligent, and attention seeking creatures they are, the more cheering was done, the more they played and jumped and swam alongside the boat. Therefore cheering everybody up and putting a more positive reflection on the trip. Now don‚Äôt get us wrong, we have heard many great stories about the whale watching trips from others, like we mentioned before, it was just our bad luck and bad timing that we didn‚Äôt get to see more.

ONE "resident" whale chased for 80 minutes. Surfaced 5 or 6 times. Saw from about 200m away for about 4 minutes in total 90 minutes each way. A number of people were sea sick. Tablets had been offered before we left.

April 26, 2018 We had a nice day with this club. The day started promising, a big group of spinner dolphins within an hour. After that... nothing... Hours and hours went by. The captain must have felt the most hated person on the boat as he was likely the only one to insist on proceeding the search for whales. Besides him, no only had any confidence in meeting these majestic animals any longer. Boy, were we wrong. It took about 6 hours but there they were: a huge blue whale mother with her baby! For quite a longtime the whales stayed in our neighborhood, giving us the opportunity to make loads of pics and vids. With a waving tail (almost like in a movie) both whales disappeared for a dive. Making the captain the hero of the day. Highly recommended!

We traveled from Kalutara early in the morning(3.30 wake up) to get the boat. It had an upper and lower deck, the seats were like tub chairs in rigid plastic fixed to the deck. Our fears were heightened when a member of the crew came around offering sea sickness pills and sick bags, we were instructed that we had to wear life jackets at all times. These were quite cumbersome and as the seats were quite snug, it didn't make it very comfortable. Although the sea appeared quite calm the boat was pitching and tossing quite a bit so we were getting jarred in the seats. A number of people were ill and went to the lower deck. We were out in total for about 5 hours and although we didn't see any whales, we did see spinner dolphins. Another boat thought they had spotted a pilot whale, but as all the boats converged it turned out to be a bottlenose dolphin. I just caught a glimpse of the dorsal fin. Although the crew were friendly I'm afraid I could not recommend this trip based on our experience as the pitching of the ship made it difficult to leave your seat.
Excellent! Nice breakfast and many whales and dolphines. Captain and workers were very professional and fast. Majestic animals.

We went whale watching and within 45 mins had seen 3 whales which was disappointing in itself as the seasickness pills made me happily drowsy and the rocking of the boat was actually quite fun so would have been super content bobbing about for at least another 4 hours on the waves. I'd possibly research a company that goes further out guaranteed. We were in shallow waters so only saw really the back on those magnificent things. (further out you'll see a tail as the water is deeper) It was still really cool and obviously the boats keep their distance. I understand some people feel uncomfortable. However the boats do keep their distance and everyone on board is asked to shut up when there is a sighting. Our company also kinda said you've seen 3 we are headed back as there are too many boats out. Difficult to say if this is a quick turn around or they had genuine concerns. Think of it as a few hours out at sea and the whales a bonus and you won't be disappointed!

A mass of boats heading our of Merissa Harbor.  Three hours out to get to the area where the whales are.  Eleven boats chasing after a blue whale.  30-40 minutes where boats charging after the whale force it to sound prematurely.  Then three hours back to the harbor.  Enough said.

Starting with a very early start from the hotel (4am) we arrived in Mirissa to catch the boat at 7am which is followed by an hour out to sea until you start seeing any activity. As with any wildlife, it is a gamble on what you see but we managed to catch a few blue whales and a couple of other types. Firstly, you may find you get sea sick but our operator offered tablets to take if required. For us, the sea was quite calm but I still felt a little queasy! Secondly, there will be many tourists boats together and they sit static with engines on idle waiting for the whales to surface, at which point they all power up the engines and charge towards the whales. They did not however seem to get too close. As the whales only surface for a minute before they dive again, you will find that the chase is often fruitless. Note: it is highly recommended that you use a reputable company as some of the ad-hoc boats seemed overcrowded and unsafe. We also got to see a huge pod of dolphins and a couple turtles on the surface. Recommended but choose the company wisely!

We spent 7 hours on a boat with fellow passengers vomiting into clear plastic bags throughout. After 3 hours in extremely choppy waters with over fifty people on top deck alone crammed onto every space on the wooden chairs and floor, we reached the ‚Äòwhale place.‚Äô All we saw was the back of one whale and the blowhole of another. A complete rip off! I‚Äôll never forget the silence on the boat. Everyone was so shellshocked by being cottaged in and having strangers literally vomiting on top of them they could not utter a sound. Traumatising. Worst part of our trip to Sri Lanka. If I could give no stars I would. We knew the reviews were mixed and we decided to chance it - we strongly recommend you do not.

The last day of our 9 day Sri Lankan wildlife tour was a 4.30am start to get to Mirissa to go whale watching.  It was definitely worth it, we saw about 8 blue whales plus a massive pod of spinner dolphins and also bottle nosed dolphins.  The sea was pretty choppy and some of our group unfortunately spent most of the trip feeling pretty unwell.  The crew of the boat were fantastic at spotting the whales and helping you to get a good view and helping you to stay standing when moving about the deck! Overall a memorable experience that really made our last day in Sri Lanka special

Though we had to wake up pretty early in the morning,the beautiful sight of the sunrise was a treat indeed. After an hour or so in to deep sea the first fight of the blue whale was fascinating. The Whale Watching Club personnel were very keen to get the maximum for what we paid and sailed furthermore to treat us with more Whales & Dolphins. Captain & Owner Rangana Manoj & his crew Pradeep,Janaka,Sanjeewa,Madhushan & Sadun took care of all guests with professional courtesy and pampered us with variety of refreshments,water,soft drinks & king coconut water.(Thambili). Very enjoyable 4 hours with calm blues sea was a treat indeed. Manoj & team,Thank you very much & keep up the good work.

A super friendly crew and a clean and safe boat provided us with a top notch experience. We spent the trip watching a huge blue whale and it‚Äôs calf surface, swim about and end the show with a raise of it‚Äôs tail before sliding back down to the 800m depth.

Complete guarantee of sighting the blue whale at least 2 times at close proximity. Well taken care of passengers and their needs. Good Safety measures. Amazing experience. Worth spending 40 USD per person.

spotting the biggest mammals in the world is very exciting but 5 hrs in crowded boat is not that easy if you have seasickness. my wife and 5 yrs daughter suffered from seasickness but crew members helped lot to overcome it.

On the face of it, it sound like a unique expierence in life in seeing the biggest mammal on the planet to witness the Blue Whale which an adult can weigh up to a maximum of 173 to 183 tonns, be 30 mitres in length & a life expectancy of between 80 to 110 years, & for ¬£30 per adult you might diloude yourself thinking this would be a good oppotunity, however the reality fails to live up to your expectations by any stretch of your imagination. Unfortunatly the chance of you getting remotly close is another story all together. Yes all the tour boat excurasions guarantee you seeing at least one that's because they they will stay out indeffinatly poss up 6 plus hours to see one. What they neglect to mention is you all sit on hard wooded seats for the duration, with no music or marine biologist informing you about sea creatures, nothing to do so you might want to bring a book or something. Most of the other tourists didn't speak much English. Ok we did catch sight of three adult Blue Whales & once you catch sight of them all tour boats are not allowd to go very close as they may frighten them & when the whale does break the surfice of the water you will see presious little of the creature. All the tour boats serve breakfast of fresh fruit, cake, fruit juice & a bottle of water. They are all insured to carry passengers, all the crew are very helpfull & are trained life-savers. There is i toilet on board, everybody is given a life-jacket. Tip. Bring your own sandwiches or something to eat as you will get hungry. All the tour boats charge the same as each other, there is no difference between one or the other. For my money i was glad to get off. I wouild not do this again & strongly advise you not to bother, but hey its your call. I can only tell you of my own expierences, somebody else may think it was great? It was quite warm on the day we went in February but i strongly advise you to bring a fleece or something.

Over one hundred people were crammed on to each boat, of which there were probably dozens in the surrounding sea, many of which belched out fumes and oil. As soon as there was a hint of whale activity all boats descended on the poor whales, boats cutting in front and jostling for a view. We both felt extremely uncomfortable to be part of this seemingly unregulated free-for-all with little regard for the animals' welfare.

Very long day on boats that only Captain Ahab wouldn‚Äôt be violently ill on. Whales can only be glimpsed at a distance. Worst of all it would seem to be very stressful for the whales to have a flotilla of noisy old boats spewing out clouds of black fumes in hot pursuit every time they rise to breathe. All that was missing were the harpoons. If you love the sea and wildlife don‚Äôt go on this trip.

Very enjoyable trip with the Mirissa Whale watching Kumara crew. Loved the refreshments and snacks provided and they didn‚Äôt disappoint when it came to finding some whales to look at. The only recommendation is to replace some of the older life jackets.

Staying two months in Sri Lanka we decided to experience as many amazing things here as we can do. One of best decisions was to go on this boat trip :) Firstly, the impressions weren't the best, as we felt a bit of seasickness and didn't see any whales for the first 15 minutes on our arrival to the point where we started spotting for them. But then, we saw the first one, then another one, seasickness unnoticeably went away and we could relax and enjoy the unusual sea walk, seeing all of those amazing ocean habitats. All in all, we saw 6 big whales including one couple of em, plenty of lovely dolphins, jumping out of the water in groups, a huge sea turtle and a bunch of flying fishes.
