The staff was very friendly and in addition, they played a bit of local music for us, singing and playing a percussion drum, which was really cool. The organization of the trip itself was really good - we had sandwiches, fruits, biscuits, juice, coffee, mint candies from seasickness and water, everyone was wearing a life jacket. Not sure what to add, but all in all we are really grateful for the trip, have plenty of nice impressions, and definitely don't regret we went for it! Surely it depends on your luck a lot (meaning the amount of the whales you see), but it's surely worth a shot :)

I have just about recovered from what I can only describe as a dreadful day ‚Äúwhale watching‚Äù from Mirissa. Everything was appalling - the most tragic of which is the stress placed on those poor animals in the water. This is not an ethical way to see these creatures in the wild so be under no illusion. There are frankly far better places and ways to see whales and dolphins in the wild. The boats are crammed full of people and the whole experience was dreadful. We spent the best part of 9 hours at sea (despite the tours being advertised as taking an average of 3-5 hours) and saw a blue whale (at some distance) for no more than a couple of seconds before it dove deep down into the sea in order to avoid the hundreds of boats frantically hunting it down. I was appalled. I would never have gone if I knew this was what it was all about. And went against my better judgement. Avoid at all costs. There are far better ways to spend a day in beautiful Sri Lanka.

The trip itself was well organized. Life jackets for everyone. Water, cake, sandwiches fruits and juice are provided during the trip that lasted 4 hours! We were in the water for 4 hours, looking desperately for whales, just to have a glimpse of 2 or 3 of them from afar!  It was an expensive affair as it costed 6500 Sri Lankan Rupees per head.The sea was also very rocky and a few of our group were puking all through.Definitely not for one with motion sickness.

The idea of seeing one of the biggest whales in the world is amazing in reality it‚Äôs no fun!  We travelled out to sea on a long slow, cold and uncomfortable journey for a good two and a half hours before we saw anything. We did apparently see a sperm whale and a blue whale but really all you see is the puffs of water and an odd tail.  They chased the whale for a further hour and a half, to see a few more puffs of water!  the whole boat were praying to just get back to the shore.  There was then the two hour journey back.  All round a very boring morning even though we did see whales, just not worth it at all!

Went on a large boat to see the whales and dolphins. Early morning start at 5am from Tangalle. Sea was rough and clearly passengers started to experience this. When the whales were spotted it was a mad dash to see them, Hubby has his toes trod on. Expensive day out together with Taxi - suggest if doing it and can afford go on a private boat

The trip itself was well organized. Life jackets for everyone. Water, cake, sandwiches fruits and juice are provided during the trip that lasted 6 hours! We were in the water for 6 hours, looking desperately for whales, just to have a glimpse of 2 or 3 of them from afar! Fortunately, lots of dolphins showed up, and were great to watch for a while.

Whale watching was on my wife's bucket list so our trip to Sri Lanka was planned to include this, unfortunately we have to agree with those reviews that compare this more to whale harassment than whale watching. Our operator, Mirissa Water Sports, displayed respect for the animals but many do not. There is a code of practice that most operators publicise but very few seem to follow, keeping distance from the whale, only one boat within 300ft etc. As soon as a whale surfaced 20 boats gunned their engines many getting far closer than recommended.  One operator, advertising Blue Whale tours on the boat, left the site by accelerating hard across the spot the whale had just dived seconds before and later displayed the same procedure accelerating THROUGH a pod of spinner dolphins we and another boat were still watching. Unfortunately for the better operators we cannot recommend Whale watching in Mirissa.

This trip was great. It's starts early doors so you also get to see the sunrise whilst on the boat (sea photo). The staff on the boat were lovely and tended to the many people vomiting because of how rocky the boat was. Although sickness isn't the greatest feeling, it was well worth it (just make sure you take one of the sea sick tablets the staff offer you BEFORE setting off). We saw a school of dolphins around our boat, sighted countless whales (may have been the same one moving around) and also tuna fish jumping out of the water. The staff served a generous breakfast too which included tea/coffee, sandwich, a sausage, a piece of cake, pineapple and a banana. I would highly recommend this trip in Mirissa. I doubt you would be able to do this at this price anywhere else (RS6000 pp- around ¬£28).

We took the tour operated by Sri Lanka navy and were very pleased with it. Leaves early morning around 6 am and comes back by 12 pm. It was very well managed, started on time and was overall a good trip. The advantage with SL navy - they have the permission to venture the deepest into the ocean permitted legally; hence better chances of whale spotting. We saw plenty of dolphins and the prize was a blue whale tail flip! Do take a sea-sickness tablet the day before to ensure you have a good experience.

We spent nearly 7 hours at sea searching for some whales.  We saw two schools of dolphins and finally did spot some small whales.  It was very choppy and the sea sickness pills they offer at the start are vital (a family we met who went and didn't take the pills ended up in the loo (not a nice place anyway) being sick the whole time.  Don't like the way the boats all zoom in on the poor creatures hounding them.  Wouldn't do this again.

We have high expections, but trip is not worth of money or time. It take about 5 and half hours, we see theree whales far away. When whale is spotted all boats hurdles around it, air is full of diesel fumes, oil at water. Whole thing was just whale harassing, not watching.

For the love of whales and all living creatures, please do not go! This is more like whale hunting/chasing ! Literally hundreds of boats chasing one or two whales! I cannot describe how awful that was! We were later told on shore by locals how whales are already dissapearing from the area and changing thier migrating roots! I do not blame them. For a mere glimpse of the whales back  or tail from miles away, that lasts mere seconds, you'll be paying big money and awfully disturbing the live of not only this magnificent creature but everything living in those waters,seriously its just NOT WORTH IT!! We went only based on the experience of my sister who went a few years back, it was a different situation with only two boats going. Obviously the situation has dramatically changed now with more than a 100 boats chasing the poor creature, if i knew this was the case i would never have gone! Its terrible ...beyond terrible and sad! Money making scam on the expence of marine life!

Out guide recommended, we did not know you could see Blue whales in this location, so thought rude and churlish not to have a look. So up at 5am and headed of to the crowded quayside to be packed onto one of the 20+ little boats offering the tour. Most boats seem to have been converted to high viewing platform tourist boats from simpler craft. So many top heavy and often listing badly when a whale, dolphin or turtle is spotted and all make their way to one side of the craft. There seems to be one specific spot all head to, and once a target is spotted the whole flotilla race to the spot cutting each other up like one big demolition derby. All trying to get as close to the prey as possible. Chaos ensues !!! Still saw 8-9 Blue whales scarpering the onslaught, also Dolphins and turtles amonst the diesel fumes and pandemonium.

We boarded our vessel with much anticipation and excitement ... then spent almost 2 hours heading out into the deep blue Indian Ocean until no land was in sight... all we could see were the 20+ other boats on the same mission.. and massive container ships in the nearby shipping channels.. a few flying fish interrupted the vastness of the ocean.. to catch a glimpse of two enormous blue whales gently rolling along the surface, water blowing effortlessly.... it was fabulous to see them but once sighted the whale‚Äôs peaceful journey was shattered and every boat in the ocean moved into full throttle filling the air with plumes of diesel smoke.. enough to make the humans even more nauseous.. let alone what it would do to the lungs of these incredible giants.. there are many reviews on trip advisor of the experience which needs to be regulated more to protect these animals and provide a better experience.. 5 hours on a boat miles from shore chasing a 60 second glimpse of whales if you are lucky -as with all wildlife experiences it‚Äôs unpredictable- weigh it up before you go

Just some words about whale watching in Mirissa. Firstly, it's a long day for a glimpse of a whale tail. If you're from Australia then you've probably seen more whales and dolphins swimming past from the shoreline of Byron Bay than bobbing up and down in deep water with thirty or so other boats chasing a large fish in an even larger pond. It was  sad to see that there is no restrictions on how close the boats come to the whales. When two blue whales finally surfaced they were surrounded by diesel spewing boats   In a circle which diminished the experience. Don't forget to take your sea sick tablets before you go- it's a very long day on the boat. Disappointing - and your money could be better spent on some of the other beautiful sights of Sri Lanka.

After an early start in the morning, we cruised 2 hrs offshore until we finally found a blue whale. People which get often a travel sickness, should consider taking medicine. The trip is rough and even the biggest ship will roll. Chances to see a whale might vary, but all captains try to get close, once it is spoted.

There are many whale watching boats going out and, as other reviewers have said, many of them are hassling the whales and going back to the harbour once a whale has been seen.  For the best experience which gives good views, respects whales‚Äô space and stays out for a good long time so that you might also see dolphins, turtles, etc, go for whale watching club.com.  They leave earlier and return later and give you a good breakfast for the same price as the dodgier outfits.

Group; We were 26 people, different ages Price: Paid 50$ for adult, 25$ children 6-12, under 5 free of charge. Duration: 7:30- 1:30 Recommended: No Value of money: too expensive, doesn‚Äôt worth it. I know it is a matter of chance to get close to whales and see them , it is not like being in the zoo But I thought we would enjoy the boat ride anyway, but it was very trying and many people got sea sickness with a lot of vomiting. Did not enjoy the ride at all, we‚Äôre tired and load voice of the boat. Saw one blue whale 2 Times  from very far away distance, saw some dolphins in the way back. I would not do it again or recommend it at all. It is expensive with few chance to get close to the whales

Many boats all going out to chase a couple of blue whales around without any real equipment to know their movements. Also no info provided about the area/animals we were chasing. Honestly I'd happily pay more in a developed country for a more ethical & sustainable experience

May be I had a romantic notion about seeing Whales in their natural habitat. I thought we and a few boats would go out to sea and just watch and wait. . I felt awful being part of a pack of boats continually chasing after these whales for a sighting. The pollution coming out of some boats and seeing discarded plastic in the sea was an uncomfortable reminder of tourism that I too had paid to be part of. With growth of tourism in this area I‚Äôm afraid this will only get worse. And those poor majestic creatures will suffer. Especially if they have babies with them. The crew and company our hotel booked were professional and welcoming. I would assume they are all much a like We did see speed boats whale watching. Obviously quicker with their chase and sightings.
I just cannot imagine coming back without whale watching expedition. Yup! we did watch this big mammal from close possible distance. Starts at 7am and returns by noon they serve good food and drink.

The difference between the various tour operators is not that significant as the experience is more or less the same: A flotilla of boats (about two dozen when we went) will burn huge amounts of fuel and create a lot of pollution on land (e.g. many, many small plastic bottles piled up on the wharf) while they chase a few animals across the ocean. Viewings are poor - few and far away - while the stress on the animals is intense. Imagine coming up for a breath after a 20 minute dive and suddenly hear 24 engines pushed into high gear heading for you. I've been whale watching in other places that are much more sympathetic and less stressful on the animals, more environmentally responsible and provide a better experience for the viewer.

We took the 7am boat (they all leave at the same time roughly) and travelled approx 1 hour off shore to where a bunch of other boats were circled around a solitary blue whale. The whale was visible for one minute, after which it‚Äôll dive again for 10 minutes; we stayed like that for one hour. Worth it as I‚Äôve never seen a whale before, but certainly only a one off type thing.

We went whale watching as part of a family event with two teenagers. The tour is dependant on the whales and also the wild life which obviously can't be planned for. During the tour we saw some turtles, several whales and a whale shark. Our hosts were great and ensured that we were not packed like lemmings and they also kept a respectable distance away from the animals which was pleasing to see unlike other operators. Id would add one word of caution - Make sure you take your sea sickness tablets as several people on our cruise became quite ill. Overall a great experience !

A day whale watching was a real experience after a 1 hour wait to fill the boat we eventually set off. After about 1 hour we reached the shipping lanes where we saw in total around 4 whales all be it from a distance without a telephoto lens you couldn't see. By this time all the japanese on the boat were violently sick which set all the youngsters off,what a noise so the boat had to go back to port after approx 2 hours.Not a very good trip. Would recommend if you have good sea legs or a strong constitution.

We were packed on a boat like lemmings, hard to see animals when they were spotted because there were so many people vying for a view.  Even people on smaller, private vessels were fighting for space around the 2 whales that were spotted. Similar to my review of the safari there is nothing "eco" about the experience.  I guess I will watch whales on my HD tv and get a better view.

He plays a good host for you in experiencing Whale and Dolphin watching at Mirissa Try to book early to get a confirmed reservation of morning slot of 06:30 AM. We couldn't get reservation in morning slot and went in afternoon slot. In afternoon seas get rough. He provides water, snacks while going deep seas. Sea sickness pills like Avomin, Emset are distributed by him free. While on return he treats you with fruits.. He takes you 12 kms inside sea to locate Blue Whale..On way you see Dolphins, Pilot whales, Flying fish etc.

We went to see the whales (and the dolphins) at 11.30am. There were only 3-4 boats in the ocean (which was good, because in the morning they Said there were at least 40boats) and we couldn‚Äôt see Any whale, the entire whale. We saw only How it removed the water (i mean we saw only the water-When it is breathing and throw the water in the air) and then went back in the ocean. And we didn‚Äôt see Any dolphin!! So...for us was a waste of time and money (6500LKR). Maybe if you go in the morning (there are some trips at 6-7am) you have more luck.

Sadly, the people of Sri Lanka often live hand to mouth and so an opportunity to create an income is obviously their priority.  We are very fortunate not to have to live like this and therefore, we view animals differently.  There is also a lack of education.  I would not recommend this activity, you do see whales and dolphins but this approach is not one to be encouraged.  As tourists, we need to push for an ethical and protective approach to view these wonderful animals.  In small boats, with binoculars, from a distance.  The noise of the boats all charging after these animals must be disturbing and interfere with animals ability to communicate.  I felt as though we were going to harpoon them, not watch them in their natural habitat.  We saw Whales in Costa Rica, in a private boat, just four of us, we kept our distance and didn‚Äôt interfere with the animals.  That was a beautiful experience. We need to change what we want, to ensure that we protect these wonderful animals and also the tourism for Sri Lanka!
Don‚Äôt waste your money unless you have never seen whales or dolphins before. Commercial process. Better options in other countries.

If your trip is less than 12 days, do not waste your time on this attraction. Do not take the risk of getting sick for the next day or 2. It is poorly planed and does not worth your time for what you will be able to see. It is about 6000 in Sri Lanka currency per person.
This was the highlight of my trip to Srilanka . The deep sea whale watching was enthralling . You get a really close look if you are lucky , this is  must  visit !!

Sri Lanka offers so much. Besides friendly people and beautiful temples and culture, also a lot of national parks and animals. Who can resist the elephant, or in this case the whale? People talk in seasons, but in Mirissa there is a part of the sea where there are always whales. Whales were one of the few animals I hadn't seen, so I had to go. My girlfriend skipped, because she had done this before somewhere else and suffered the two main problems: (a) not seeing whales and (b) getting VERY sick. From that moment, I was a warned man. And I did what I had to do: ignore warnings. So one day later in the very early morning I was sitting on the board with the first people. Things were taken care of, so we got swimming suits, breakfast and ..... pills against seesickness. Could my girlfriend be right? I took the pill, was surprised by the amount of Chinese people and we left. Within a few minutes you realize the sea is wild and the boat is light and shaky. My stomach is reminding me of everything I did wrong in my life. But I've been through worse and would sit this one out, staring at the empty see. The first noise was not from whales, but from our oriental friends who seem to be puking in harmony, a lot and loud. Can't remember laughing harder than that moment. Until a new noise. Someone saw a whale. Not much, just the back, spitting water in the air, and going down, showing us a glimmer of a tail. And again, again and again. You don't see very much, but you see it. Whales, from up close, slowly, relaxed. From the most beautiful things, we only get a glimmer, because it's real, not staged. This is one of the most beautiful moments in my life and I am forever grateful that I got to see 7 maybe 8 whales, whom made me forget I felt sick for a while. Than it's over and you realize the way back is a long way. The sickness comes back. I asked for the bag, which I didn't need because I could fight the sickness. And I had to because I had something to prove, after laughing so much at oriental people who got carried down from the upper to the lower deck. Some looked more dead than alive, but the noises of sick and puking Chinese people made me realize they all survived. I hope they enjoyed it as much as I did, and I hope you will too.

I agree with the other reviews that the boats were far too close to these beautiful animals, which becomes a race, which isn‚Äôt  right. I think these animals are better viewed from a distance. It was clear there are not a lot of whales out there, which the guide books don‚Äôt tell you, which is why I think there is a big race to follow the fee we did see. I think the whale watching companies need further training how to respect the wildlife, personally I think they have scarred away the whales.

You'll see some whales, but there are no rules and no respect for animals. As soon as one appears, all the boats rush to circle the whale approaching as much as possible, it looks more like a boat racing than a whale watching. Go whale watching in another place.

Took an early morning trip far out into Indian Ocean - on-board breakfast included in ticket price.  Trip lasted about 3 hours.  Boat had inside cabin but a covered but open-sided top deck allowed for uninhibited viewing.  After a while, there is was - a great Blue Whale breached and displayed its massive tail for the cameras!  We had about 3 sightings (don't know if it was the same whale or different ones), some dolphins and flying fish making an appearance during the trip.  Boat crew all very pleasant and helpful, ensuring passenger safety at all times.  Complementary sea-sickness pills dispensed before trip started.  Another experience ticked off the bucket list (whale-watching that is, not throwing up over the side!).
Amazing close ups of many blue whales. The tail flipping dives are the highlight. Far exceeded my expectations and so soon after the cyclone hit SL. Plan second whale watch tomorrow.

Perfect, highly recommend. Incredible nice and very fit for the job personnel. Environmental friendly, safety first and taking care of the animals (even if there are people nagging that they want to be closer to the whales). Very reasonable price and can only be booked on-line or at the office of whale watching club in the harbor of mirissa. We had a great time and saw about 10 blue whales !

what an experience ! start out in the morning with expectations. and we land up seeing a whale breathing, surfacing and diving - multiple times. the skipper of the boat was simply superb. dont miss this experience !

I was very hesitant after reading all the reviews about the terrible experiences people had but I decided to risk it and I am soooooo happy that I did. First of all our boat only had 10 people and I did see other boats that were packed. I used Horizon tours on their smaller boat that cost 6000 rps. The bigger boats charge 6500rps. Onboard we were all given a life jacket and sea sickness pills which I gladly took even though I do not suffer from this illness. After reading the reviews, I felt it was better to be safe than sorry. The waters are definitely choppy. Very difficult to stand or move around on the boat once we leave shore. So my suggestion, get a good seat and stay out. We were served water, sandwiches, juice and fruits. Even though the sea was rough, no one on our boat got sick. And of all the boats out that day, 4-5, we were the first to spot a blue whale, literally next to our boat. Huge whale, Full length, big tail .....an unforgettable experience. I have to admit there is a bit of luck involved because there is no way to guess where the whales will surface, after their initial dive , we were told they would resurface on 10-15 minutes but they can resurface miles away . So it was just pure luck and the keen eyesight of the guys on the boat to spot them and chase after them. After our first upclose sighting, we saw a few more much further away and got a close up of some dolphins and turtles. Again it was just luck of being in the right place at the right time.  We came back early, in 4 hrs and left all the other boats at sea still searching as they were two far away and missed most of what we saw. Worth the risk.....the whales are massive and beautiful creatures. Plus if you enjoy a bit of adrenaline pumping  ride, you will enjoy the boat ride. I thought we were going to capsize a few times. It's exhilarating .

It feels like huntingüê¨üê≥, i feel bad for the creature, it was crowded as well, there are like 6 or 7 group of boats trying to catch a sight of the the whale, we also saw dolphins, it was an amazing experience but I'm sorry for disturbing it. The government should post schedule of whale watching with time limit, they should also give it some time alone. Its just disturbing.

This is the worst experience ever! We arrived at 6:15am but the boat did not leave till 7am! No one told us what to expect during the trip. 10mins after our departure i got terribly nauseated ( although i have been in boat trips many times before) the sea was tough and it was raining but the boat was moving at a crazy speed! I asked to be returned to shore since the trip is 4h long but my request was rejected. 20mins later half of the passengers were already vomiting as well. The weather was awful, the water was all over the floor, the rain drops were hitting us everyone was wet and one could smell vomit all over the boat. After 1h30mins of high speed travel we arrived and personally saw nothing! Then travelled back for 1:30h more. We arrived back to shore with no power to move i have never been that sick that angry or that disturbed! We canceled the plans for the rest of the day and went straight to the hotel to sleep all day long! After that experience my husband and i decided to cut our trip short. Totally not recommended!

Firstly the trip duration is 5 hours, not 2-3. You need to be there to buy a ticket at 6am. The boat leaves at 7am and you will be back at 12pm (5h on the sea). We went in october, end of the rainy season, so the sea was not quiet at all. The boat was moving a lot (all boats are very similar about 70 seats on 2 decks). 90% of the passengers vomitted. It was a nightmare. And to see what? Almost nothing: back of whales with some water thrown outside. Few hours of sickness in the middle of people vomitting for that? I saw humpack whales in Cape Town Massachussets: it was amazing: the whale jumped outside the water, play with their tales near the boat. But in Mirissa nothing. May be no much luck or may be not the right season. Anyway in Province town the boat is much better and does not move much. Here we were thinking the boat is going to sink. Never again.

When I found whale watching Mirissa website and sent email to them. They reply me very soon and confirm the booking with me. When we reach Mirissa Mr.Ganidu Rochana arrange tuk tuk to hotel pick us up to the dock. During this trip we saw a lot of whale even when my friends felt motion sickness they give a bed and let her lie down even me as well. The team is professional and careful of people. We strongly recommend to choose them to whale watching.

An awesome experience..from the start of the boat ride..it was an amazing journey..where you get to see a whale ..well that‚Äôs reason enough...and you also get to see a few dolphins along the way..but make sure you bring your sea legs..or take some meds before you get in..or you are going to be puking with all the others and end up missing the action..make sure you visit!

One off the must dos at Mirissa in Feb. There are several boats which will take you on these tours, you can  book it through your place of stay or anywhere in the town or just at the beach. I booked it through Raja & the Whales and totally enjoyed their tour, very professional team.

This was the reason why we planned Our Lanka Trip.. Whale watching !! There are many places from where u can do this, but the most popular is Mirissa.. I got packed breakfast from the Hotel & My Taxi dropped me at the Jetty. The provide u with Mineral Water & soft drinks in the boats. My wife didn't accompany me, as she thought the sea would be wild & she has sea sickness, also someone had informed that it takes atleast 4-5 hours in the sea to get near the whales & come back. So she opted Out & it was a big regret for her later.. The Sea is not that wild in March & even the Boats r huge to bear the waves. 45 mins after we left the shore at Sunrise we spotted a cluster of Dolphins, there were lots of them after 30 mins from there we sighted the Whales !! what a sight that was.. Mesmerizing !! it came with its head out & then gently moved its body & lastly it showed its Big Fin & went under the sea, this happened again, but unfortunately i could capture the video & not the photographs :( (U need really good camera's for this) & what a luck, another boat called us & another whale was sighted & this one was very near. i could see it few feets away from me.. & even this performed the same feet !! & we came back to the shore, again from the dolphin point. i was lucky to complete the trip in 2 & half hours !! i can still close my eyes & see what i had seen then !! Whale watching is a must must do in Sri Lanka !!

Somewhat of an adventurous outing. Good for everyone who would like know the challenges of the ocean.There could be some uncomfortable feeling if touring for the first time.But get rewarded with the view of whales and dolphins in their natural habitat

Just wanted to give people a heads up on the whale watching. We booked at the hotel we were staying at and were picked up at 0630 for the boat. When we arrive we found the main deck consisted of 8 seats across and about 20 rows,  there was an upstairs, however we we told we could not go there, although for some reason others could, this was not explained to us. The boat continued to be filled to capacity downstairs, whilst a member of the crew handed out seasick pills and life jackets which we all had to wear. This was not good so I went to get off the boat, asked why and told them I was not happy being sardined in, secondly why could we not sit up top. No problems go up top. People continued to arrive on board, I finally thought it unsafe to go when two more buses arrived. We got off. The Sri Lankan navy was there and the coast guard, not sure why, and the man with a automatic rifle didn't make me feel any better. I am not suggesting all tours are the same, but certainly Good Boys Tours is more concerned with their welfare than the customer. Footnote: a plus was that the hotel returned our fare no questions asked. Buyer beware a guess, so find out how many passengers will be going
We have watched 2 blue whales for couple of times its move fast and boat driver sometimes can't make it so see us close view but still it's good activity

We were unsure if we should do this or not, because we read is was low season and there wouldn't be any whales, but we are so glad we did it. We saw whales 5 times. So incredible. The both was not too crowded because of the low season, but the sea is rough and 1/3 of the boat got sick. But if you are okay with waves, you HAVE to go :-) anazing to see those animals!

Because we are visiting in August we hadn't expected to see blue whales....but we did! The boat trips start early, the sea can be fairly rough but the crew offer sea sickness tablets. The boat headed out to sea until you can't see land, all the time the crew were scanning the water's surface for the distinct spay of the whale's blowhole. We saw many blue whales, well mostly the spray from their blow holes and then the length of their backs. Once we saw one whole tail! Amazing and well worth it.

You will see several whales (maybe its one family). You will go there by boat maybe 45 minutes and 30 minutes you will hunting the whales with another 3 boats. But I can recommend it. The Best boat is Eagle eye. The Red one.

Woke up really early, left Colombo at 4am to reach Mirissa for whale watching. Around 730am the boats full of tourists left for the open sea. Many people including us preferred to sit on the floor of the top deck by the railing instead of the seats. It was fabulous, the view. We were offered cookies and tea. After a good hour and a half into the sea we spotted them... It was mostly a big fountain of water sprouting from nowhere followed by a much smaller but distinctly visible one, suggesting a mama whale has taken a baby whale out for a stroll... As soon as the staff or any of us spotted them the captain would speed up towards them... We all got a chance to take pictures. One whale even dived just below our boat... We got back at around 2pm with an awesome experience and good memories to share

The staff seemed friendly but unfortunately the trip was very poorly operated.  The boat was very crowded and overbooked, people were sat on the floor and there was a struggle to find everyone life jackets.  I was asked to wear one that was rated for 10kg below my weight.  One of he staff said my "baby" needed to sit on my lap, she is 8 and I refused as a 3 hour trip with an 8 year old is ridiculous when you have payed a lot for a seat. We were told that breakfast would be provided, having left our villa at 0530 we were quite hungry by the time they came around with a tray of very tired looking hot dogs at 0730.  We were given one hot dog and one bottle of water to share.  Never take this trip hungry, the food provided is terrible. The weather was appalling and we got to see very little in all honesty, maybe 3 whales from about 150m away.  There was a big storm and the sea was rough, several people were pleading with the staff to return but they wanted to carry so people wouldn't complain.  I would estimate that 90% of the passengers had bad sea sickness (luckily us excluded).  There was a constant stream of sick bags being passed out. The storm then blocked us from returning and we had to sit and wait it out in terrible conditions.  I apologised to my family for taking them on such a bad trip, when getting off the boat we were asked for a tip by the staff m, my tip is to anyone thinking of taking this trip, "AVOID!"

Was really disappointed by this trip - it was far too touristy as an experience although luckily we were with one of the smaller boats and got fairly close to the Whales and had expert boatsmen. However when we spotted whales we were followed by another 15 boats charging behind us.

June may be off season. And so the sea is very rough and the whales stay away. It's a long long long journey - 7 hours or so. Everybody other than 2 or 3 people were sick and red puke bags were the most seen item. It's so bouncy that you can't stand forget walk or try to use the toilet. For a 1 min dolphin school sighting and a 5 sec whale back sighting it's really not worth the trouble. If you pop the seasickness pill, avoid food (the serve a hotdog and juice) and water for the entire time you might come back in one piece to write a review as I did.

I have gone on this trip with my family in this year. Beauty of this is if the whether is  good you will be able to see Dolphins and Whales both. You have to go in to deep sea and spend about 2hrs. full trip will take about 5hrs. Boat will provide the refreshments you have to relax and wait till the excitements come.

I visited Lanka with family and friends last year December and visited Mirissa primarily for the Whale Watching experience that turned out to be quite disappointing!! This whole thing is a sham. There are 20-30 boats, loaded with over 100+ travellers do roughly 2k-3k tourists. The is usually a small (faster) boat with some sonar equipment that is constantly looking for the whales. The moment they spot a whale they change their raise a flag and all other 20-30 boats rush to the as spot. The hundreds for travellers on the boat start pushing each other to get to the front or the sides (whichever side the whale is spotted) and in the end you may be lucky to see a 2-3seconds of either the back or the tail of a whale from 100-200 meters of a distance!!! Horrible experience in spending 2-3 hours on a boat overpacked with tourists for a 2 seconds spotting maximum 3-4 times that too far far away ( you didn't expect to see the whale at an arms length, it will fling your boat like a paper boat). There are lots of things to do in Lanka don't get excited by the title - Whale Watching and end up with a pain in you know where.

We got to see 4 whales this morning and I was ecstatic! The crew gave us seasickness pills and a bit of food beforehand, and even had plastic bags at the ready. They constantly looked out for the passengers and offered them plastic bags once they observed that they look unwell (I even got offered twice, but managed to keep it down throughout the tour). My friend and I fell asleep while traveling to the whale-watching spot but the crew politely woke us up to alert us about the whales. I would also like to commend Ganidu (the contact person you can make your reservations with) for his honesty and efficiency. I accidentally left my phone in the life jacket pocket and only realized it when I reached my hotel. After I called, he immediately went to check the life jacket and managed to find my phone, even instructed one of his tuk tuk drivers to deliver it to me at the hotel. Thank you so much to the crew and Mr Ganidu!

It was a wonderful experience watching those Dolphins and Whale's. We were a 14 member family group. The cruise members ensured to show us those Whale's - they have never give-up attitude. Their service was good - as Whale watching starts early in morning - they understand well the needs of tourist. Thank You.

We went for a whale watching ride yesterday and it was very fun!  We reserved a ticket for the upper deck to have a better spot scouting the ocean for a blue whale.  Which we did. Numerous of times. Friendly crew who prepared snacks!

Great opportunity to see Blue Whales.  We saw about 4 or 5 whales.  The only downfall was the the boat was crowded and the people on the other side of the boat would have had an obstructed view, but well worth experiencing.

Our hotel organised this trip for us for a discounted price and it was well worth it. We saw three wales and 4/5 big groups of dolphins. Amazing day, got breakfast and soft drinks included. Well worth it. Only downside was that the sea was a it rough, and literally half the boat was being sick. Tip: Don't sit by the bins all the bags of sick go into!!!

The very best there is! The kaptein and his crew are very careful for the whales and the visitors. Good care, good service! You wil always see blue whales with the whale watching club. Nice breakfast, drinks and food. We can recommend them for the best tour!! We saw al lot of whales nearby and large group of dolphins. Very nice! The kaptein and his crew are good whale spotters. They respect the nature of the whale and all the nature. They will not hunt the whale. That we liked a lot!! Kind regards jet peter dick jeannette From the Netherlands

It was a very poorly run operation, boat overloaded, crew not helpful and blocked passengers views of whales by standing in front of them taking their own photos. Waste of time and money better things to experience in this beautiful country
Try your luck with whales and dolphins. Pick a good tour company to do the tour! Great for all ages especially the kids.

While the company we used were very friendly and provided a good service, we would not recommend whale watching in Marissa. There were dozens of boats which went out in the morning. They all followed the same path and when a whale was spotted they all sped towards it, by the time we got close the whale had disappeared. It came up for air every 20 or so minutes and we saw it from a distance for about 15 second before it dived again. We did sea a large number of dolphins which was quite impressive, but overall the experience was under whelming. The sea was also quite rough and people were throwing up so I wold mot recommend going if you get sea sick.

A must do when on the south coast. We were lucky and saw about 6 whales quite close they were swimming at the surface and spraying. We also saw a turtle, and the dolphins were flipping and jumping for us. I've only ever seen flying fish on TV so that was impressive too. We were in awe of the big Blue whales and seeing them in the wild was just breathtaking.
We saw whales and dolphins and it was great time! Sailors take a care, bring the food, fruits, cakes! I enjoy it so well

This is a must see but you need to have a good sea stomach as the boats pitch roll and bounce on every wave lol they do offer sea sick pills so take one else you'll be in the technicolor yawn gang as many are, I never suffer but took one anyway It's a long ride to the whale area and the whales are there all the time as it's their home turf but your not guaranteed to see them as they can surface anywhere within a few miles and once they do only for a few minutes but...... it's a great site when they do so be ready you'll hear them first, I think I only saw one whale a few times but it was good enough but you only see a small part but still good enough Once the whales surface every boats speeds towards them never getting too close and sometimes when's there's more than one they pop up next to you if your lucky The staff are great and knowledgeable and they feed you as well if you can stomach it lol Enjoy

I joined the trip on my first day at Mirissa as it is highly recommended. The price is pretty high but it's worth. The price includes breakfast, medicines (for those who suffer from seasick), drinks and tour guide. The Indian Ocean was so turbulent that some women on my boat started vomiting after just an hour being on-shore. It was lucky that I saw the whales, some dolphins and a giant sea turtle. Good cameras are advisable if you wish to take some cool photos of the animals. The trip lasted for around 5 hours. You may spend at least 2-2.5 hours before the animals appear.
this is very adventurous and exciting . You need to start early into the sea and look around you and you can see many whales tossing and jumping.. Really its a treat to your eyes.

We got in a nice boat and were seated on the top deck.The sea was very calm on a wonderfully sunny day. We were given a packed breakfast which was ok but not really tasty.That was not important. The ride was excellent and we enjoyed the nice calm sea which was so blue and pleasing to the eye. We saw a few whales but did not see any dolphins. I recommend this trip to anyone who likes to experience what we had.
Had a fabulous day out with a great crew, good fun and took great care of us. Saw in excess of 15 whales but sadly no dolphins, next time maybe. Food and drink offered on the boat free of charge.

It's nice trip by boat. Price is between 1750-6000 per person. Price depends how good you are in discussing about it. Be prepared it can make you sick, but they give you seasick pills on boat for free. All trip takes you about 3 hour. Boat is starting at 7 a.m. local time. They will offer you on the boat coffe and some snack :)

Maybe I had unrealistic expectations but I was disappointed to find myself on a large tourist boat packed in like sardines all trussed up in bulky life jackets. We saw whales but at a great distance which most people seemed ok with, the photos were not worthy of a Facebook post. I have been on similar trips in Oman and South Africa and had a great experience on both trips.  Sadly this experience was a distant 3rd place. I will say we booked through our villa host ... if you book more directly via the re-sellers on the beach you'll see the pictures of the boat and have a clear idea of what your getting
We actually managed to see four whales. The captain and his gasts took good care of us serving snacks and drinks. This was definitely one of the highlights of my holiday

On 1st March, my husband and I boarded this boat for some whale watching. We were given life jackets but no instruction on how to wear them properly. For example there is a strap to pull up between your legs which prevents the life jacket from rising up over your head should you end up in the water and can prevent a broken neck. We were then given a box containing a roll and a sandwich plus done water. Many people were on the upper deck and some of us on the lower deck. We set off at 07:00. About 07:30 the boat was really rocking and spray coming over the sides. It then started hammering down with rain and a storm started. It was at least a force 6 or 7. My husband has 20 years of marine experience and he realised how dangerous the situation was. The side flaps were pulled down and people from the upper deck started to come downstairs soaking wet. Sick bags were handed out and at least 75% of the people were vomiting. There were three children on board who were crying. Some of the adults were very frightened. A number of people asked the crew to turn back. We were reassured that this would happen but it never materialised. We asked for an announcement to be made about what was happening but this didn't happen either. At one point my husband advised me of what to do should the boat capsize. He was concerned that the flaps on either side were pulled down which meant our exit was blocked. As we were in the rear seats he told me that I should drop my bag and go quickly to the back of the boat where there were no flaps and we should have been able to escape from the boat. They wanted to let us see a whale. I assume it was because they didn't want to issue refunds!!! Once we had seen a whale the boat was turned around and we returned to harbour. By this time it was 10:30. When we returned we discovered that out of all of the boats, possibly 20, which went out at the same time as us, all but 2 returned quickly. No apology was given and certainly no refunds either. I would definitely NOT RECOMMEND using this company due their obvious lack of adherence to safety.

A FABULOUS HALF DAY EXCURSION.left port around 7am. After about half hour cruising into the Indian Ocean we encouted our first "there she blows " a beautiful sight seeing these majestic blue whales just cruising along. Would highly recommend this trip. There are numerous boats , all with life jackets , but I would book in advance via your hotel to avoid dissappointment.

Yes, we saw wales. But the whole thing takes 5 hours starting very early morning, and you see whales for 15 seconds. Our captain hurried back and was just a routine activity. Dont take the pills cause you will sleep during the trip, be aware not to get sea sick. When the whales are visible tens of boats surround this poor animal.

A fantastic experience! This is a brand new boat with super friendly crew. The best and most beautiful in Mirissa. We had an amazing experience and will recommend all our friends and family. The good boy boat is faster than other boats so you do get to see whales first before other boats arrive. On your trip you will spot turtles and some flying fish too. Great experience!

This was an horrible experience.  This is more like whale hunting,  just without the killing. It's 15+ big boats with 50-100+ tourist on each chasing the poor whales around the water!  Please, take of the "tourist glasses " and see what's going on around out there,  if you take the tour.   I would never recommend this to any one.

We took a whale watching tour which was quite successful in as much as we spotted four whales up reasonably close. No dolphins however which was disappointing as they were what I was hoping to see - the previous day they spotted around 100. The refreshments were great but one comment I would make is that a few more seats are made available upstairs - especially as some of the guests are mature age so find it difficult to squat on mats on the deck.

They were very careful on the whale safari. First, they have insurance for you, which is something you only wonder about when it is too late to ask. Second, they are associated with the hotels (our hotel had the same name - Paradise Beach Club) which then allows you to check out only after you are back from the safari and had a chance to take a shower. And last, but that is more luck than anything else, we were able to see the tails going down five times in a row in a single sailing, which was great. See some photos I have taken during that safari.

We went on a trip with the company called Whale Explorer.The trip was awful and dangerous. A crew of relatively young guys just wouldn't give up searching for whales despite the rough sea. All other boats returned to port. People were feeling and getting sick, some of us were asking to return to port. They insisted on continuing until we saw whales.We ended up seeing the tail of one whale and a 45 sec view of a side of a whale. They announced that they had done a good job as we saw two whales and expected to be congratulated, since they perservered whilst all the other boats returned to port. My husband said he was going to complain and a crew member told him not to cause trouble when we got back to port. He was very aggressive. We also did see one other boat that was overloaded and looked in danger of capsizing in the rough seas. Plan your trip, ensure they provide good fitting lifejackets and go with a company with good reviews. You will most likely get wet.

We got to see a blue whale on our whalesafari, which was an amazing experience for us, but not so much for the whale. There are many boats and as soon as the whale reaches the surface the boats rush towards it. The whale seemed to be stressed by this and spent less and less time in the surface to avoid the boats. Make sure you go with a company that respects the whales as many does not follow the rules and go too close. After seeing it five times, the crew told us we would head back and give the whale some space. People started to complain that we only saw one whale. I think we were pretty lucky to see one blue whale several times..

We went with Geeth after reading reviews and him and his staff were excellent. Some of the other boats were overloaded with people and black smoke was coming out of the back of the boats which makes you wonder how long the whales will stick around in the area. Some of the boats were dangerous showing little regard for other boats and the whales. The trip was great as we got to see some whales and it appears that it is better to pay more to ensure safety and no overcrowding. We were provided with breakfast, water and sea sickness tablets if needed.

Down to the busy harbour to board our boats around 07.00. 2 decks and everyone has to wear a life jacket. As part of a hired boat with several small groups our boat was one of the least overcrowded. One boat I noticed jam packed and listed in the waves at some 70 degrees, not for me.One surprise we were offered food including sugared rolls - delicious and this was  part of the trip. [didn't need pre packed breakfast]. About 7 boats headed out to sea. Firstly came across dolphins and eventually whales who were spotted by the expert crew and who proved to be a great help. Two separate sighting with the whales performing for everyone. Once goal achieved we headed back to shore and the fishing harbour.
Do not trust the agents,go to the port a 6am and pay 2000 rupees any agent will try to make high commission.rest all ok Whale's are visible.

Some boats are really overcrowded (like mine) and it is hard to see anything since all the people are rushing to the side where the whale is spotted. And all you will see is some water that the whale is blowing, hardly anything else. We also spotted the fin of the whale, but that's it. There are so many boats circulate the poor whale that I felt so sorry for the whales out there and regretted the whole boat trip. My advice is therefore: save the whales and your money - don't go!

Well, we should all have the opportunity to see these amazing marine mammals in their natural habitat. You have a choice, so be careful of what you choose. 10 fully loaded tourist boats pooring diesel fumes into the air as they all chase down a mother as she try`s to protect her calf. The boats definitely keep there distance, but they all contribute to constantly chasing [harassing] these beautiful sea creatures. The choice is yours. Unfortunately, not theirs.

We are a family of 4 (two kids, 2yo and 4yo) and we were a little afraid after reading some reviews that had 6-8 hours journey. The boat left the port at around 7 and come back at 10.15am. It was quick and efficient!. We choose Whale Watching Mirissa with Geeth, and bought the tickets online in advance (very easy through paypal). The boat had the perfect amount of people, not at all full. We saw some boats that were scarily full!!  We saw several whales, hundreds of dolphins and a turtle!!! The captain always sailed respecting the whales or dolphins. The staff was really nice and helpful!. They were always making sure the kids had a good place to see everything. They also help us carry the little one so we could make some photos or carry the other kid up. They kept looking in all directions for sea creatures. Breakfast was provided, including bread, cake, banana, sandwich, tea, crackers and water. Great Experience!!

We went with Good Boy Eco Tours in a fairly large boat.  If we went again I think I would choose a small boat as it would be easier to see. We saw many dolphins, perhaps eight blue whales -  and a couple of green turtles mating! It was worth doing (if only to watch all the very excitable Japanese youngsters on our boat!), but the whales were not the sort of size that David Attenborough would show you!  Closest encounter was probably around 50 metres, but most were further away.  Do not bother with binoculars - the boats are not stable enough. Some criticise the operators for hounding the whales, but I saw no evidence of this - if the whales have had enough they simply dive.  Remember too that they actually choose to live in a busy shipping lane!

Most whale-watching boats just follow each other and offer the same sort of stuff. Blue Ocean provided very tasty breakfast, were very knowledgeable and respected local ecosystem. We had three sightings of 3 different Whales making 9 sightings in total and saw a couple of giant turtles as well. Best to go in Dec & Jan as sightings are pretty much routine. All done and dusted by lunchtime - back to the beach!

We left a hotel in Mirissa at 6am. The boat started at 6:45am and the journey ended at 11:00am. The staff requested us to wear life jackets, though they did not tell us how to wear them correctly. We saw turtles, dolphin, several whales and a whale shark. The staff went around the yacht to assist those with travel sickness. They kept looking in all directions for sea creatures. Breakfast was provided, including bread, cake and water. It would be important to bring a wind cheater and to take sea-sickness medicine before as the sea could be a bit rough.
Saw a bit of the back of a whale, some dolphins and a turtle. That's it. Not worth the money. My boat kept chasing the dolphins to have a closer look but was a waste of time.
We had an awesome time on whale watching tour.. we were lucky enough to see few sperm whales and turtles... best time to visit is Dec and Jan as probability of sighting whales is about 95%..
It is worth watching Whales, Dolphins, Tour takes 3-4 hours, I was lucky to see 5 whales and 4 Dolphins , 2 flying fish,  2 huge turtles , Don't miss it, it happens in the morning at 8

Tourist money fleecing caper. There must have been 10 reasonably big boats, crammed with sightseers, literally chasing after a whale sighting, of course, the moment a whale surfaces only to be surrounded by boats packed with people yelling ' oooohh' in unison, the whales first reaction is to dive, so whale watching could be better described as whale brief distant sightings. I've been whale watching before, in smaller boats with less people and time to sit and wait peacefully for surfacing whales. Chasing them down to get a good photo in the allotted 3 hours isn't what l expected. But hey, some people thought it was fun, the same people probably went elephant riding later in the day.
Worth to see.  Simply book thru your hotel or hostel, do check price before pay.  Price shown on ticket r6500 but in fact we pay r3000 for rooftop seat.

The ferry left around 7 am. It was a great day as we started seeing glimpse of blue whales sprouting far ahead. The guide calmed all the excited passengers saying we will see more whales at close range. True to his words, we didn't have to wait long to see 5-6 more blue whales. Was very satisfied with the tour and the boat turned back heading towards the shore....and suddenly there were a group of dolphins chasing our boat. This was a bonus for all of us. The boat returned to the shore around 10.30am with a happy crowd having seen a bunch of whales, dolphins and a sea turtle. Great tour.

We saw some blue whales yesterday with Mr Nadeesh's tour (on the Eagle eye boat) as well as some turtles. Once you've got your seat on the boat, everything is v well organised & you get food/water & a good explanation of what's happening everywhere, but the booking & seating process was a bit confusing. We met Mr Nadeesh on the beach & he had cheaper prices than the other guys on the beach, so were v careful to ask about which boat it would be for & whether we could sit upstairs etc. Once reassured that we could choose wherever we wanted to sit & the boat was a decent one, we booked. The pick up came as arranged (a good sign), but when we got to the boat they tried to tell us that upstairs was reserved & we had to sit downstairs. Luckily the guy we'd booked through was there, so we called him over. He wasn't v convincing to the guys on the boat disappointingly, but we kicked up enough of a fuss to make him sort it out. It's shame as he seemed nice & not like he was trying to trick us, but I'd definitely recommend watching out when you book what seats are included & that you make things v clear when booking. We enjoyed the trip after the bit of hassle at the start...

So we met a chap introduced himself as Mr Ganesh on Mirissa beach, nearer the east end, by the big rock with the steps up to the top. The average on the beach was, we found, around 2000LKR per person, Mr Ganesh undercut this by 500 and after finding one other quote from a chap in an actual high street shop for 2500, we settled with Ganesh. The only gripe I've got with him is the only one anybody ever does - he's a big ol' fibber basically but we did describe and agree - very clearly I thought - that we'd have seats upstairs on the two-deck boat and not down. He lied on 2 counts; that the price was the same throughtout - patently untrue once you factor in private charters and families paying through the nose for additional services, and that there was free movement between both floors once the boat was on the move. I noted on other boats the latter may have been true but this was very much a designated seat, on your deck, not a free for all, which seemed safer of course. I mention this only because you may require your 'game face' at early-o'clock once you realise that's all up for negotiation. I also want to emphasise that I have no prejudices at all and if i may validate: I'm a scotsman living in London so I'm not unfamiliar with being lead on - I absolutely didn't take any of this personally nor am I trying to paint a disagreeable portrait of a nation and i don't begrudge him a living at all, this is just the way of it sometimes. We saw Mr Ganesh at around 6:45, having been picked up by tuk tuk promptly at 6:30 as agreed and dropped at harbour. After signing into a register (Name and nationality) we boarded and headed upstairs to find ourselves being shouted at (in a friendly manner mind you) that we're not going there. I got fed up pretty quickly but in a perfectly decent fashion, jumped off the boat, got mr Ganesh (who'd been hiding whilst I was waving at him from the boat - 2nd alarm bell - and walked him down to the boat where he shouted something at one of the boat folk. This, it turned out, had not been 'These lovely people have been told they can sit upstairs; sit them upstairs' and resulted in us basically ignoring the shouting and walking upstairs to grab some seats. We were told seats had been reserved simultaneously with 'you can't reserve seats' which said to me unless you pay more or double you aren't guaranteed a top seat. Not guaranteed, but not denied either, and once everyone was seated we grabbed 2 remaining seats and settled in. Bear in mind we only got the seats we actually booked from sheer bloody-mindedness, which is not my preferred MO on holiday. Sorry for teh long explanation but I figure the details might be of use. ANYWAY! Over to George Dawes and the scores on the boards - another minor hustle as we'd seen for 4 days here the boards had several hundred dolphins listed, apparently large schools hang out in regular locations. We didnt see any, in fact all we saw were two copulating turtles, which was kind of amusing when the other boats started arriving for an ogle, and a blue whale. But over all of these minor quibbles and the lacklustre count the fact remains - I SAWS ME A BLUE WHALE! and that may well have been worth paying double, especially when the big beast slapped its tail down on the churning waves. I'd even, almost, at a pinch, recommend Ganesh, if you can be front it on the day (go on I know you can) with a big grin and not-taking-no-for-an-answer charms, then get involved and as a bit of insurance you could eeven record whomsover you got the tickets from speaking into camera (in english only) and saying 'Top Deck MOFOS guaranteeed' I only do upper deckers.
Very helpful and smiling. Very good experience in mirissa We saw blue wales and turtles. They take the time to have good moment

We booked our trip with the Sri Lanka Navy well in advance. We got to the Naval Base by 6.30 as asked, but there was delay and we sailed off only at 7.30 am. The ship was excellent with air conditioning ample space comfortable seats etc., They served us breakfast before take off which was quite good. The Navy personal were a very friendly lot, ever willing to help in every way. They look after the little children, the passengers who felt sea sick. It was a very pleasant trip in the whole.  We saw quite a lot of whales, but not many dolphins. The captain was very concerned and maintained the distance of 100 meters away from form the whales as was the requirement. But there were private boats that did not keep to this and was disturbing the mammals. Hats off to the Sri Lanka Navy for a job well done.

We booked a day trip from Unawatuna through a company called best tour Lanka. The itinerary meant leaving at 5.45am in order to get to Mirissa for 7am, which we were fine with, given the guarantee of seeing whales that the tour operators provide. We paid $70usd for the transfer and he boat tour, which seemed quite pricey by Sri Lankan standards, but we assumed that we would get a car there and back, leading to the high cost. We were collected by a Tuc Tuc, leading to a very cold 1hr trip to the harbour, and questions about the cost of the trip. The boat we were taken to was already absolutely jam packed by the time we arrived, meaning we had to settle for downstairs seats on the inside, limiting our view significantly. Fortunately we were able to head outside and stand at the front of the boat once we made it out of the harbour. Once we were at sea, it was clear that there wasn't much science or organisation involved. The spotting consisted of 10-20 boats turning down their engines and waiting for a plume of water within eyeshot. Then it was a high speed and incredibly dangerous race to the area where the plume had occurred. This was rarely productive, as the whales were obviously on the move constantly. We did see a few animals cresting the surface within 50-100m of the boat, but this seemed to be more luck than judgement. In one mad chase, we came within approximately 1m of colliding with another boat. We were at least 5-10 miles off the coast at the time, and this could have spelled disaster for both sets of passengers had the 'captain' not been able to apply his rear thrusters in time. We did have life jackets, but there were no life boats and around 150-200 passengers on each vessel. Given the number of whales that appeared to be present in the waters, based on the plumes we saw, this whole operation seems like a waste. With some expert consulting to improve the crews tracking skills and more organisation/regulation of the companies and boats, this could be a much more enjoyable and safe operation. Instead, it feels like a chaotic and underwhelming disappointment.
We were able to witness four bigger blue whales during our whale watching trip. My wife enjoyed it a lot.

I've been traveling across the globe since 1996 and this was my worst travel experience. There was no pick up in the morning. Despite several calls, the vehicle never showed up. I took a 3-wheeler and reached the harbor. Mr. Ganidu Rochana promptly received the money and assured seats for both me and my wife. We entered the boat and the deck was full. Mr. Rochana vanished from the scene. The crew said that the seats are for "white tourists" and we both need to go to the upper deck and sit on the floor. It didn't matter that we paid is the same sum and we were assured seats!!! I called Mr. Rochana who conveyed that he is on his way to the harbor gate to receive some European guests and can't come to the boat!! I've asked the crew not to sail and call the cops. They acted as if they didn't understand!! We wanted to get out of the boat. By the time we reached the lower deck, the crew started sailing!! There was no point in asking them to turn back since the boat was already away from land. I had to yell at them to get two life jackets when we were heading towards deep sea. There was a Sri Lankan family with kids on the upper deck who didn't have life jackets while the boat was chopping across rough seas. The crew didn't have enough life jackets. By God's grace, weather was alright and that family reached back safely - not sure how authorities allow such risky business. We did see whales - but, it's not worth the risk or humiliation which we had to go through. There are plenty of other professional agencies in Mirissa and Galle. If you want peace and dignity, just avoid Mr. Ganidu Rochana and his firm. We had to leave the next day morning to Colombo and I couldn't file a complaint. I can't comment on the experience of tourists from the Western nations, but if you're from India, just stay away from this provider; your money and peace of mind will be ruined. It's a shame to deal with such touts in a mesmerizing and serene place like Mirissa. Another lesson learnt is to take the lower ratings in Trip Advisor seriously!!
Fantastic trip.  Felt that this company were the ones to be with as looking at other boats they seemed overcrowded and quite fast when approaching the whales. Raja and the whales brill.

Early start, sandwiches and fruit offered on the boats. We took the larger boats because as booked by our hotel. The staff were great and ensured everyone was looked after. We saw one blue whale and a couple of other sightings in the distance but by the time we got close, the whale had gone back underneath the water. As some passengers were loudly complaining (rather selfishly I thought), we headed back early but the guides were saying usually they stay out until you get a good sighting. Thankfully we were fortunate enough to see 30-40 dolphins swim up and around the boat. It was exciting and took the edge off not getting a good sighting of the whales.

We got really good price, 1500 rupies, which was the absolutely the highest price that I would recommend to pay! The trip itself was nothing special, long and pretty rough boat ride so if you tend to get seasickness, prepare with medicine! Breakfast is included (a cup of coffee, two sandwitches and later a popjuice) but if the whales are hard to find, the trip can be long! Finding whales was actually pretty funny, around ten boats chaising the whales like crazy, turning around when a whale is seen. We also saw two tutles and really quick a few dolphins ‚ò∫ We were on the trip from around 7 o'clock till 11. The sun started to burn after 8 so take a sunlotion with you!

I found this was a LONG trip in and out and not worth it. So many boats, so much pollution, the emissions from the boats are disgusting. If I had my time back, I'd not have gone on a whale watching tour.

My wife, daughter and I were delighted to be able to see Spinner dolphins, turtles, a pod of pilot whales and a blue whale.  All close enough to take good pictures and not disturb the animals themselves.  It was a long hot day, in life vests.  We set out at 7am and were back at around 2.30pm.  We were given breakfast and the boat went out into the shipping lane around 11 miles out.  There were another 10-15 boats out with us, all packed with people - some dangerously so when everyone piled over to one side of the boat to see the whales.  It was an amazing experience and I would not have missed seeing the whales. It is another thing off my bucket list.  However, I would take water, decent sun screen, a hat and a decent pair of sunglasses so you don't get eye strain from the reflections off the water.  The operator did kindly supply sea sick tablets to those who needed them and had water on board for those who wanted it.  The crew on our boat were very helpful, but I am not sure that is the case on all the boats.

I'll start with the good - I was part of the 'lucky' boats, that fortunately were always closest to the whales when they emerged from the ocean. It was magical to see the large blue and sperm whales, but that is where the magic ends. It took 1.5 hours to get out there, with a 5.30am start (from galle). We had paid an extortionate amount of money (6500 LKR) each (4 people) when other companies were charging 3500-4000. We were told this boat was better, with less people and a 'breakfast'. The breakfast consisted of a sandwich...not really breakfast when you've been up since 5am and will return to land at 12pm. The worst thing was that the poor whales were hounded. Each time the whale was sighted, all 20 boats (with at least 50-100 on each boat) would slam their engines into gear and hurtle towards their prey. It must have distressed the animals greatly, with one moment being especially upsetting when all 20 boats created a circle around one animal, leaving it with no where to go until it took enough air to go dive. People sat, applauded and laughed with glee, with no understanding of what is happening. I am by no means a 'hippie' nor 'eco-warrior' - but these are supposed to be protected oceans, and the sri lankan coast guard was even present, which surprised me as they let this happen on a daily basis. $10000's is spent on whale watching, with little regard for the animals safety or wellbeing. I was lucky to have 40 minutes out on sea before heading back as that was enough. Some people I heard had been out there for 7 hours just to see a single fin. Don't support this is my final point.

We had such a lovely time aboard Atlantis that we decided to go again. Our first trip was on 11 December and we decided to do a follow up trip with some friends a week later. We saw blue whales and sea turtles during both trips. Tip: Ask to be seated on the top deck since it has the best views. There is a demand for top deck berths so book it in advance. Amal, the captain, and the crew are really nice and helpful. They educated us on the habits and migration routes of whales and provided breakfast, a cup of tea and a plate of fruit. Such bliss for such a reasonable rate! Before we chose Atlantis, we did some research on rates of whale watching boats. Atlantis gave us the most reasonable rate, compared with the other tour operators. You can call Tharindu (the owner) directly on 0094779191614. We highly recommend Atlantis for a fun and laid back whale watching trip.

The company we sailed with, Whale warriors, was very well organised: good breakfast, coffe or tea, water, lateron fresh fruit and juice. We had to sail for 2 hours or more, to find two blue whales in quite a distance. We also saw some Dolphins and 3 turtles. But all in all a long trip for just two whales.

Travel guide talked very little English, and made out this trip was a personal experience where you could also swim in the water and snorkel. Well I was in for a shock! My partner, myself and our 4 y/o were collected at 5am to travel down.When we arrived, I soon realised this wasnt going to be the relaxing day I was hoping for - hundreds of sight seeing boats. We were the last few ushered onto this disgusting filthy boat. Nothing was explained to us, and the guys operating spoke limited english. Once we set off, we were handed sandwiches, and shortly after sick bags were handed out! was pure hell having to listen and witness everyone puking up into dog poo bags, and then chucking them into communal sick bag bin! We were on the bottom floor, so had the displeasure of seeing the people above us puking over the sides too and landing in the boat. Apparently we saw 3 whales, but there were so many people on the boat rushing to the sides, the captain had to run down and even the boat out as we were at risk of tipping it, great! after 5 hours of pure hell, I could eventually see land, and the best bart of the experience was getting off the boat!

Too many noisy boats and not much luck with the whales üò°üò¢. We mainly came to watch whales. The Palace Mirissa is a wonderful place with bungalows and a restaraunt set on a hill with beautiful ocean views in well looked after tropical gardens. But disappointed with whale watching üê≥üêãüòêwe had bad luck

I went on my own on this trip as the rest of my family didn't want to have to get up at 5.20am! We got to the harbour at 0645 but the boat was delayed leaving as it waited for another group. This meant we were always at the back of the fleet when searching for whales so it took a long time before we could get close enough to feel we had seen the blue whales. It was an uncomfortable feeling to see a pack of 30 boats of different sizes haring off in the same direction when one of the spotters sighted a whale. The whales didn't stay long on the surface once the pack got close to them - can't blame them for that! All in all I have mixed feelings about whether this is a good thing to do. We weren't given any talk about the whales and their conservation so it has no educational benefit but I heard that these tours have been useful to local people rebuilding after the tsunami. It was amazing to catch a glimpse of the largest animal on the planet but it would have been better if some education had been included too and if we could have been assured that the whales weren't disturbed by the boats.

There are quite a few negative reviews here about whale watching trips in general and probably deservedly so.  If you're considering going whale watching in Mirissa then please go and read the reviews of Raja and the Whales - these are THE ONLY whale operator you should consider.  They are slightly more expensive but it is worth every cent.  They are the only boat trip not to chase the whales or get too close.  Other operators had overcrowded boats and did not seem to understand anything about sustainability or respect for these creatures.  Raja kept well away from the other boats that would crowd around whales in a big convoy of boats - simply disgusting.  The Raja crew are, I believe, the first whale operators in Mirissa, they appeared to have all the knowledge and knowhow and respect for the whales.  Plus they served up a very good breakfast and fruit during the journey.  Afterwards they collected our email addresses and sent us the photos from the day (which was just as well as we'd elected not to bother bringing our camera phones).   Nobody on the Raja boat was disappointed.

If you have never seen whales then you may find a trip like this worth it, up at 4am from Hikkaduwa and not home til after 3pm..but living in Nz and having seen many whales this was a mistake for us! Sea sickness pills are given and a small breakfast and water which was nice but sitting all that time on the boat was very uncomfortable and once we finally did find one whale all the boats went off chasing it, you might get a photo of the whales back or tail from far away but I don't know if anyone ever really sees a whale breaching like in the pictures! We wished we had spent the day on the beach, just felt like a waste of a precious holiday day spent sitting in car and boat feeling tired and sick...

This trip delivered exactly what we wanted - close sightings of Blue Whales. We went with Mirissa Whales which operates a fairly big boat (130 seats), is reassuringly safety-conscious, has knowledgeable, friendly staff. and is respectful of the whales. We arrived at 6.30am for a 7am  departure, and were told we would spend up to 5 hours looking for Blue Whales, returning once we had got good sightings. Water, a breakfast sandwich and sea-sickness pills(!) were included in the price. We were very fortunate - our first, rather distant, sightings came after 30 minutes; then after another 15 minutes we got a series of much closer sightings of 2 adults. Our boat kept a decent distance from the creatures - close enough to give us a good view (improved by our binoculars) but not so close as to disturb them. And, having seen them at this distance for 30 minutes or so, we returned to shore, getting back about 9.30am. Excellent.

One of the most popular activities in Mirissa is going on a whale watching trip ‚Äì this is the biggest tourist trap I have ever seen. Everyday overcrowded boats leave the harbour to hunt for whales. Literally they hunt for whales ‚Äì all boats were chasing madly at the whales. Once a boat spotted a whale, all the boats go in the same direction and it turns into an ugly chase, scaring the animal. It is very tragic to see that they do not respect the Whales ecological environment at all.

Really really really wish we hadn't done this trip - the boats are not really suitable for going so far out to sea on a rough day.  It took about 2 1/2 hours to reach the area where the whales frequent, that was 2 1/2 hours of sheer torture with the boat pitching and yawing constantly all the way.  They give free breakfast but I would advise you not to partake unless you want to bring it back.  They give out seasickness pills - definitely take one but unfortunately they didn't seem to work for everyone.  We were fortunate and didn't suffer but many others on the boat were constantly being sick in little black plastic bags.  We did get to see 2 or 3 whales blowing but that was pretty much it......Then, you have the horrible ordeal of having to travel another 2 1/2 hours to get back to harbour.  The most unpleasant trip of my life and I could not wait to get back to land, and I normally love boats.

It was a memorable experience. We started our trip at 7.00 am. The crew were well trained and supportive. There were around 70 passengers in the cruise. We spotted 1st whale around 10.30am. We saw the whale spaying water while swimming deep in to the sea. Time to time several whales appeared (partial view) to the surface and it was an exiting moment. We came back to the shore around 1 pm.
