I probably sound crazy with that title...Well, I am being sarcastic but also stating reality. If you really want to enjoy this trip, PLEASE turn off your smartphones and cameras! There are tons and tons of pictures and videos on the net. Don't ruin this experience for yourself (and do this favor for others as well) just to be thrasonical. Now for the trip - There was absolutely no communication about how long the trip will take. To make matters worse, the guide said it would take about two hours, instead, it took 5 hours!! No, I am not blaming the whale :-) but the tour operators could have done a better job to explain what to expect. As far as the whales - yes! The operators do their best to spot but give them a break if you don't get the best view. It is WILDLIFE after all and as I said whales don't like selfies. In our case, we were able to spot quite a few of them (Lucky us!!) but the experience will  be better if us Tourists can learn to stay away from gadgets and enjoy the sight of largest mammal and do the favor of not blocking the view of others' on the boat. And please refrain from moving to just one side of the boat; they tilt. Last but not the least, it was very sad to see people throw trash into the ocean.

We were so looking forward to this trip as it sounded amazing with the chance of spotting different whales.  We have done this before and do understand nothing is certain with nature. But what a let down.  It was a 4 hour trip out to see with some spinner dolphins seen on the way, and then search for whales. There were I think 10 boats most presumably in contact with each other. After a long wait suddenly all the boats headed in one direction. Over the next 20 minutes there were tiny glimpses of ONE blue whale. It's the biggest mammal in the world and we hardly saw it. Cheers and straight back to harbour. Trip took almost eight hours.  Unless you really enjoy long boats trips simply not worth the effort, much better in other countries :( Would definitely not recommend.

We went whale watching with company Danushka and we can't complain about them. We felt safe, got seasickness pill, breakfast, tea and cookies. Everything about this company was ok. The problem is that there is too many companies providing the same service. There was about 9 boats(including Raja and the whales who are the most expensive) chasing three poor whales. When one boat saw the whale, another 8 started speeding towards it. Whole experience was a bit dissapointing. Sure, it was nice to see the whales glazing through the sea but it was just too big intervention in their habitat.

An absolute must do, if not done before. The ocean fills you, and seeing a Blue Whale and Orca (Killer Whale) is an experience. Photography is not easy, at times the visual moments are only for a flash, unless you are an experience photographer give a priority to the naked eyes rather than the camera lens. Precaution: Don't have a heavy breakfast, take an anti emetic, the ocean even at its calmest, can toss our insides.

We were offered a whale watching tour in Sri Lanka navy's passenger vessel "Princess of Sri Lanka". It was a group package and it was a very interesting and entertaining. The tour is available for individuals and groups as well. individuals on weekends and long weekends and will cost (Locals LKR 3,500.00 without snacks) and USD 60.00 foreigners. The vessel leaves the Galle port around 7:00 am. Advance booking required and could get details from whalewatching.navy.lk. It takes around 5 hours. Snacks are provided for a additional nominal charge. If you have not been in a ship before be prepared for sea sickness, the Navy staff are good, helpful and friendly. Sit in the middle part of the ship near the window, as it appeared very bumpy compared middle dock. Once you reach the location, you are allowed to go outside and wearing a life jacket a must to go out. Inside the vessel is air-conditioned and if you prefer can watch from inside. if you are lucky, you will have a smooth sailing and will get a chance to see many whale and dolphins. We were lucky enough to have a smooth sailing, sighting of around 10 occurrences whales ( probably 3 or 4 whales).

One off the bucket list - very early start and went way out to sea but worth it to see the beautiful blue whales in the wild. Boats are large and fairly steady but go a long way out. Still well worth the trip............

The whale watching tour was the worst experience while we were in Sri Lanka. We wanted to have a good time while whale watching because it should be an amazing experience to see blue whales around you. The boat was crowded and some people didn't even had a seat. We were like 50 people on a small boat. At the beginning of the whale watching the crew was friendly but they turned into thiefs when one of them stole my cap and told me that a tourist might have stolen it. In the end I found it. The crew was hiding it under the life jackets. We were driving 35 kilometres on the Indian Ocean in order to see whales or turtles. Indeed we saw some but 90% of all passengers weren't able to stand up because they got seasick due to high waves. The crew used the moment when we were all hanging in our places and stole caps of helpless passengers. They made fun of all the seasick people. Absolutely worst thing ever. Be careful and don't eat the bread they offer before the drive! You might get seasick! Be prepared. Enjoy beautiful Sri Lanka without this whale watching trip! Definitely not recommendable. Better save the money!

We took a whale watching trip in the end of October. The trip itself was nicely organized, we had small breakfast and tea. There were some whales swimming but do not expect spectacular views (maybe because of the "low" season). We saw a tail of one and that was it. And be prepared for a sea sickness. Our boat was affected in 90%, not sure people actually enjoyed the trip itself :)

We saw 3 blue whales very close up. The best we saw surfacing for about 90 seconds. Everyone was able to get a brilliant photo of the dive. We also saw several other whales spraying from a distance. We were worried about seasickness as we went just before the season really starts. However, we felt fine and only one of the 20 or so passengers was sick or felt sick. I slept on the 90 minute ride back to the mainland. The whole thing took about 4 hours.

I really can¬¥t understand the good reviews I am reading about this attraction. For me was a really dangerous experience I would never recommend. Be aware the trip is very far, just to get to the whales spot takes two or three hours (of course you have to come back after so add few more hours), and if the sea is rough, it is a long long trip, in my boat the 85% of the people was sick. The boat is old and not well maintained, the engine didn¬¥t work properly, once we stop to let a cargo boat pass, we got stuck in the middle of the ocean and the engine could be turned on... after trying several times at last it worked. Many of us asked please to come back, but the crew refused because they want to get paid and show us at least one whale, who cares about the safety... Really bad experience...

Friendly staff on our boat. We got to see what we were there to see, a whale.  I think it was a humpback or a sperm whale. The sea was really rough, and quite alot of people got sick. Wouldn't do it again in that weather.

Whale watching is being organised from Mirissa and Galle port by Sri Lankan Navy, two times per year. One during June-July and another in November-December. The booking is required to be done beforehand and usually the trip begins at 6-00am. Very nice arrangements are being made by navy. The journey is inclusive of fooding. But u need to take some medicine before u get into the ship to avoid sea sickness. Ship will go the the middle of sea where whales are being found in pairs. Sound of water throwing is audible from far. Apart from whale sometimes dolphins can also be seen.

WARNING - Unless you plan on feeling shocking for 3 days afterwards because you have sicked out everything in your stomach then don't do this trip besides January-April. I hate being embarrassed and despite taking a sickness tablet, I very quickly became ill. My stomach hurt so bad that I started crying. I hate being sick infront of anybody and I think I cried out of embarrassment as well. It was such a huge shame as I was so poorly that I could barely lift my head. We did see a whale and that was incredible and I'll remember for the rest of my life that I saw a whale's tail lift out of the water but I'll also never forget how poorly everyone was including myself. I think if we'd done this a different time of year then it would have been a dream come true experience but it turned out to be one of those stories to tell the grandkids when your old because of how bloody awful it was! Such a huge shame. Amazing seeing the whale. Terrible stomach ache for days afterwards though.

DO NOT DO THIS IF YOU ARE PRONE TO MOTION SICKNESS (even if only slightly prone). This may sound silly but I did not quote realise how bumpy the ride would be and ended up feeling incredibly seasick for the whole trip (and remainder of the day). Saw 2/3 whales, but compared to other whale watching experiences I've had it wasn't nearly as good.

It was pretty nice experience to make this trip. It took 3 hours at all and we saw three whales,no dolphins. It costs 2000Rps. Photos we took were bad,because it was difficult to catch it or it was far from us. We got breakfast and water at start. Many people on the boat had seasick because of the big waves. We were ok luckily‚ò∫ It is better to stay/sit on the prow-foredeck. But they give plastic bags to everybody.

We went for a trip with my boyfriend. I had already a trip in australia and i was expecting for something similar. But this was absolutely different and a would never do it again day! The sea was rough and the boat was small so we felt like we would travel on a matchbox. Everybody on the boat got seasick and wet from the waves. It was totally unprofessional. Not like a whale watching trip more like an adventure on a rollercoster on the water. Though we have seen 3-4 whales the boat was very quickly driving further. It was a 3 hours terrible trip from what the whale watch part was maybe 10-15 mins. When we arrived back to the harbor, the locals had an ironic smile on the tourists , like they knew it that everybody will get sick...

The boats are happy to take your money but don't warn you how rough it is out there. I would say 80% of people were sick, despite travel sickness pills being handed out. We did see a few whales but only just and no dolphins. PIctures were woeful. Given how expensive it is, it's worth asking around how good the trips are at the time you are travelling.

It did not impress me much. Thankfully we only paid 2000 rupies/person so it was not that much. We only saw 1 whale (3times) but 2 times was just a splash of water. In 1 try we actually saw the whale in his full lenght. When he dissapered into the water the men on the boat just said now it's time to go. We didnt even try to find another ones or even some dolphins. If you decide to go, try going during the season ;)

I was sick for the whole thing so if you're anyway prone to motion sickness AVOID AVOID AVOID! We did catch a glimpse of 3 whales but I was too sick I couldn't really see. By the end of it more than half the boat were getting sick. Maybe we were out on a particularly choppy day so best to check the conditions before heading out.

Although it was not high season we went for the trip. Fun it is when you have sealegs otherwise you will end up looking into a plastic bag like on our trip about 80% did see that. We seen a whale a few times and it was good. Lucky for me I didn't get sick so the boat rip was a nice experience also.

The whale watch season goes from November to March and of course nobody will tell you that because they want your money. We went on august and it was a rip off.. the sea was really rough and everybody got seasick. We only saw a small tail far away while carefully vomiting in a small plastic bag (kindly and rapidly provided by the crew). 4 hours of nightmare until the crew asked if we wanted to see more whales..nobody could answer being too busy vomiting. Go only in the right season, when the sea is calm and the opportunity of seeing whales is real.

To make the boat, that leaves Mirissa at 7am, we had to be up for a 5.30 pick up (from Hikkaduwa), but thought it would be thoroughly worth the effort. The boat was scary in itself - I was very dubious about getting on it at all with my three small children. If I hadn't insisted on life jackets for them, they wouldn't have received these as the crew had a very relaxed (not in a reassuring way!) attitude. Once out at sea, I was totally scared - the boat was rocking about like a rollercoaster. The kids seemed to find it fun, but about an hour into the trip, 80% of our fellow passengers were vomitting into plastic bags. It was certainly far from enjoyable for those vomitting or those not! We didn't see any whales (a few dolphins, which was nice but certainly not worth the 3.5hrs on that awful boat!). There was nothing else going on during the trip to keep our minds off the vomitting passengers, lack of whales or scary conditions (eg perhaps if someone had been telling us about what wildlife generally exists in the area etc it would have improved the experience). My kids eventually fell asleep out of boredom and I guess from the rocking rythm of the boat. We have subsequently giggled about the experince but I certainly would not recommend it to others. I guess seeing the whales is partly luck on the day, but even if we had done, I am not sure it would have compensated the boat and vomitting....

Forget about an intimate encounter with the whales, the boat is quiet large & packed, if you can get there early to grab a good seat (we sat on the lower deck which was fine). The free breakfast is a sandwich which was edible but if you are a fussy eater bring your own food. You are given a life jacket (out of date) but the boat was overcrowded & does tip alarmingly when you sight the whale but as someone else said on the boat "if we capsize there are lots of other boats around to rescue us". It takes about an hour to get out to the whale watching area & the day we went there were about 6 other boats most equally packed. We got to see a turtle & a blue whale 5 or 6 times so it was well worth it. Talking to the crew you are pretty much guaranteed seeing whales.

Spotted whales least 6/8 times. We had a great time. Raja and his companions tried best and made sure all on board get to see what they paid for. Highly recommended. My 3 year old was so excited. Loved it!

It‚Äôs a mix feeling I have after coming back from this trip‚Ä¶.I was happy as well as disappointed‚Ä¶To be able to see the Blue Whale‚Ä¶‚ÄùLargest Mammal in the World‚Äù was mesmerising experience‚Ä¶We managed to see it couple of times but it was after a long haul journey of 4 hours, sea sickness‚Ä¶We saw some flying fishes on the way and unfortunately we couldn‚Äôt spot the dolphins neither the sperm whales as others could‚Ä¶ Yet it was worthwhile to see the Blue Whale couple of times going up and down and not like any Hollywood movie that people imagine but definitely worth a watch! It is very important to go with a good operator as they do not go overboard and disturb the natural habitat like others do‚Ä¶We went with Whale Watching club and they respected the distance unlike the others who chased after the Whale which can be dangerous for humans as well as the Whale‚Ä¶Once must choose carefully and Srilanka Tourism Department should make the licensing a more restricted business than giving it away to every boater. Respect Nature and it will respect you back and with any wildlife watching one needs to be patient and that‚Äôs what I have learnt whenever I have gone anywhere‚Ä¶ So must see for people who have patience but not worth for people who feel wasting a whole day to watch the rarest species on earth is a waste of time and effort‚Ä¶ They can plan something else while in Srilanka as it has plenty to offer!

You have to get up very early. These boats are overcrowded and bob around like corks - not good if you get seasick. Clouds of black smoke come out of the engines to complement the marine environment. If you do see something, people stand up and block your view. We only saw a few sperm whales for a few seconds - obviously other people have been luckier. Very overpriced but staff are perfectly nice. These boats now acknowledged to be a threat to the one very special area in the world where blue whales do not migrate. Do the whales and yourself a favour and drive on.......

We went during the off season but we're told that for the past few days the whales were around. So thus we signed up with Club Mirissa for whale watching. Since it's the off season operators would quote sky high charges. During July only 3 boats were plying for all the infinite whale watching clubs in the harbour. We were quote as high as Rs. 6500 for upper deck but finally got it for Rs.2800. We enthusiastically reached club Mirissa at 6am. It's good to have the sea sickness tablets at least half an hour before the travel. There were only 50 passengers on the boat we took. The sea was really rough and choppy. People started vomiting half an hour into the trip and were finding it tough to even go to the lower deck as the boat was tossing around. We went around for 7 hrs in the sea returning with a quick look at a sea snake and a manta ray. Not even dolphins. It's recommended that you do not take the trip during rough seas as it's highly unsafe and may not yield any results.

Hey friends, If you happen to be in sri lanka specially south sri lanka & have never gone for whale watching then I would recommend you not to miss going for the whale watching experience.Be prepared since 4-5 hours is normal for entire trip. You will leave from the harbour around 7am.Light breakfast is served before the journey.Please do ask for sea sickness medicine if by chance they forget to give the same. I was blessed to see pod of 15 sperm whales and dolphins.amazing experience since we were 50 meters away from the whales.If you favored u might get to see blue whale as well. Don't miss the chance...Go for it!!

We travelled in monsoons, when the place is officially shut for tourists. The sea was stormy, the cruise dirty and the guide well greedy. Please be prepared for a long haul, it takes a minimum of 4 hours , and the sight of sea sick travellers around you could completely put you off. They guarantee you about sightings, and the trip usually includes a cold breakfast, that can be avoided

I was inspired to see whales after watching the movie 'In the heart of the Sea' and was surprised to read that whales are always there, in Sri Lanka and Mirissa is the place to be.Now I salute the special effects and graphics experts of Hollywood cos in reality it didnt look anything like the movie.Not even 1/3 of the size seen on screen. I could be making a mistake by comparing it to a movie, but apart from this like someone who mentioned earlier this is on the whole a not very interesting activity as the whales stay underwater for about 15-20 minutes and you are luck if you see the water shooting out and manage to rush to it, just in time to see the tail going underwater. That is all that you see. ( I was even wondering if this was a setup with a man wearing a mermaids tail and surfacing every 20 min !)

Be prepared to spend the whole day out! We were expecting about a 2-3 hour trip but the Whales were far out so we ended up on a 7,5 hour round trip. Well worth it we saw 2 Blue Whales as well as about 100 dolphins and a green turtle. Hats off to the crew who made the effort to find the whales.

This crowded boat trip lasted for 8 hours. We did not bring any food because the organizers said they would have take care of the breakfast. One sandwich, on small bottle of water, some biscuits and a juice. That's all for the all day trip! It was hot, and long, like hunting a ghost. Whales no where to be seen. On the way back the toilet was disgusting, no one cleaned it. We ended up seeing some dolphins and few flying fishes, really not worth it the price. At the end our day was wasted. The claim that they will give you another ticket for the next day is a myth. No one said anything and when we asked they seemed even upset. The guy just said: come again tomorrow at six, I'll get you on board. Well, we thought, never again.

I'll start by saying that we did see whales. So this isn't a review about not seeing whales. We saw them, the tourists cheered and the other boats raced towards the whale. If that's your sort of thing then great. If you are a responsible traveler then not so great. We saw whales after 4 hours on the boat.. 4 hours. Doesn't sound too long and then you remember you have to get back to shore, and the boat only goes at one speed and that's another 4 hours. We were on the  boat for a total of 8.15h. That is a long-haul flight. People were sick on the boat so all in all probably the most unpleasant of environments and not worth it at all. Felt like a waste of a day when holiday time is precious. Returning to the whales briefly. Whales used to swim near the coast of Sri Lanka, then the tourist boats got too close, and closer, and the whales got further. So now the boats have to go further out to find the whales. Not only this but the whales don't do the lovely high tail dive you see on nature programs. They do shallow tail dives which is a sign of stress. Sad really and if I had known this before I would never have contributed to the practice.

I had a couple of whale-watching tours in February 2016. The tours more than matched my expectations. We had excellent sightings of the Sperm whales (pod of 20), a lone Blue Whale and Spinner Dolphins (pod of 200+). The diving whales and the spinning dolphins were a thrilling sight to behold. We could ride alongside the whales for a long time, because the boats maintained a safe distance from the whales. The tours were conducted Mirissa Water Sports, a professional and well-experienced team. The boat was spacious and clean. The crew were well-trained and very helpful. They were knowledgeable about the marine animals. All in all a memorable experience.

This was one of the only two horrible experiences during our 15 day stay in Sri Lanka (the other being the Turtle hatching farms). It is an accident waiting to happen. I do not want to name the opetator we used because I think they just do what all other operators do. They were actually nice, offered fresh fruits on the way back, coffee upon arrival, sea montion medication and it was not a crowded boat (as I saw many out in the sea). Nonetheless, it is a very long day and it was tiring and hot for getting a few glimpses of the whale every now and then. I could NOT believe on the number of overcrowded boats out there, all chasing madly at the slight glimpse of the whale. I am positive this is distressing for the whale and as an animal lover, this is a total no-no for me. This happened several times and at one point I counted 12 boats all racing after the same spot. On boarding, some of the briefing included instructions to remain in our seats so that the boat would not tilt to the side with the most favorable view. This off course was ignored by all the Chinese on the boat with one fat woman running from one side to the other taking photos. That would make the boat tilt very dangerously to one side and I am hereby predicting that this is an accident waiting to happen. I know it is a matter of time. Also groups of very disrespectful people standing and blocking people's views made this a very unpleasant experience. It is not worth the money the uncomfortable heat the foregone sleep the obnoxious people the long journey for a glimpse of the whale especially given what I think it is unfair to the animal. The dolphins swimming along the boat makes for a phenomenal view but having seen them last year in the Galapagos (without having to chase them), I feel the setting here is not appropriate. If you care about animal welfare, please do not go on this. If you have children, please do not take them out for this. It is unpleasant and unsafe.

I cannot find the operator of the boat that we were unfortunate enough to go out on. It was called JET LINER. Apologies to these people if they are not the culprits. Avoid JET LINER at all costs. Our boat was dirty, massively overcrowded, slow.and there were not enough life jackets to go round. We were out over 6 hours and only saw dolphins. We saw many other faster and less crowded boats which I guess gave a much shorter but better experience. There was no shade for many of the poor passengers on board and it was nearly impossible to move around the decks to reach the toilet. Refreshments were promised but the very few crew gave up on any attempt to distribute the small bottles of water and sandwiches.No safety or whale information was given out....in fact there was no communication whatsoever once we had boarded. An absolute nightmare and we were relieved to get back on dry land safely. The operator of this boat should be prosecuted.
The whole trip was a bit disappointing to me as we only saw 2 or 3 whales and dolphins barely showed up. It was too long, like 6 hours or so, and wasn't really worth the time.

Very early start arrived at 6.30 having booked an upper deck seat to find non available. Paid 6000 each for the trip and have just spent the most uncomfortable day of my life. The boat won't turn round until it finds a whale and we spent 6 hours at sea before spotting one, great to see but not worth the effort or sheer discomfort. Lunch was a cream cracker and a banana !! Saw some fantastic Dolphins but not a nice day out, won't even go into details of the one toilet for 85 people. I spent a total of 9 hours on this boat and feel robbed, time is precious. If you have young children a definite no no.

The whole concept of whale watching just cannot work. Whales can dive for 20 minutes which makes it really difficult to get anywhere near the whale because as soon as you are getting closer it will dive and appear in another 20 minutes far away. Once one of the boats spots the whale all the boats go same directions and it turns into a really ugly chase, scaring the poor animal. We went with a good company and managed to see the whale from distance but the overall experience was still very poor. We spent 4 hours on the open sea on shaking boat before we managed to see a splash of a a whale and in that moment noone cared about it anymore, we just wanted to be back on the land. It's really not worth it. If you like animals and want to see them in their natural environment go to Uda Walawe national park instead.

First of all, to select a great operator to have wonderful whales watching is the most essential for such adventure event.  Otherwise, you will just too bad luck to be a follower to chase to other operators to see nothing. Protect our oceans for future generations.

I was very excited to see blue whales (the biggest animal in the world) but unfortunately the trip was quite disappointing. Having been on other whale watching trips in the US and Canada where the whales were a foot away from the boat, this trip didn't quite measure up. It was a very long trip which would have been fine if there had been a lot to see but as there wasn't, it was quite tiring. We waiting around a lot to see whales spouting water in the distance. Had a quick glimpse of a part of a whale's back but not much more. The dolphin family that swam near our boat was lovely but not sure it was worth my trip down to Mirissa and the 6 hour boat ride. The company that I went with is top-rated and I think that their service was great which is why I'm not posting this on their TripAdvisor profile. Maybe it was just the day that I went but whatever it was, it was disappointing. Trip is not cheap- I expected much more.

Experience: Good. As blue whales are not very common, you can also say it is worth watching. You need to go to deep in the ocean. So there will be hell lot of water bumps. So keep this fact in mind before planning for the trip. If you have motion sickness, you should prepare yourself accordingly. Procedure: You can purchase ticket from the site or you can collect it from your tour operator. I recommend to collect tickets from your tour operators. After purchasing tickets tour operators will take you to the sea site. Normally ships start their journeys at around 6.30-6.45 am. So you better get their before 6.30 am. Ticket Price: Ticket price varies a lot. We bought tickets LKR 6,500 per person. But I heard from my fellow ship mates that some of them bought tickets as low as LKR 3,500 as well. So please bargain before purchase.

Wowo wonderful experience I have ever had in my life. I love it How o do? There are many many service providers in Mirissa area. you have to place a booking before you go. You have to reach to destination early in the morning on or before 6.15 am. Most of them are leaving at 7 am. This trip takes around 4 hours. Mostly you can see blue whale and dolphins but according to experienced people there are killer whale once in while you can see. All and all it is good experience

We spent 5 hours bobbing about on a fairly large boat looking for whales and I was left with mixed feelings about it all. There were around 25 boats all doing the same and as soon as there was a sighting there seemed to be a mad dash to get to them and then the jostling for best position started. It certainly couldn't be described as a personal experience and at times I felt like a pack animal hunting its prey. The people on the lower deck seemed unable to follow the most basic of instructions such as do not all rush over to one side of the boat which mad the whole thing tip at an alarming angle whilst also ensuring those on the opposite side on the upper deck couldn't see anything; idiots.  In addition many people showed no respect or consideration for others by standing up and thereby blocking the views for the rest of us. We were one of the lucky 3 boats out of the 25 (so we were told) that actually got to see some whales; 3 blue whales one of which was 35ish metres long. Personally I would not take my children on this as it did not feel safe and I would not repeat this experience.  For anyone wanting to desperately see whales in their natural environment then I would research the best places around the world to go ie highest probability of seeing, good safety, low visitor numbers etc and maybe even consider paying the extra for a private tour if you can afford this. Sorry to be so negative about this but this is not an experience I want to repeat

I went with a Chinese family as a tour guide to see the whales and dolphins first time in my life. I was so excited to see them as I heard and saw on Internet but unfortunately we couldn't see the blue whales but we saw two killer whales far away. As per the boat caption he said if killer whales are enter we will not able to see blue whales or dolphins and we had to return back after we travel around 3 hrs one-way in to sea. By luckily we saw some dolphins on our way back they where stick to fishermen and travelling to gather. Hope to visit again on my next trip.

I enjoyed a morning whale watching with this operator, and saw two blue whales, plus dolphins and turtles.  Of course, all wildlife encounters involve a degree of luck.  The operator was responsible and met with the codes of practice for whale watching e.g. not getting too close, not crowding the whales, not cutting in front of them.  That is more than can be said for some of the other boats around.  So I am glad I chose this company. The boat was in good condition and has two decks, a lower deck with seating, and a standing upper deck.  Good views and visibility all round.  Both decks have awnings providing shelter.  Be warned the sun is very strong and you may not be able to wear a hat (or notice you are burning) if its windy, so ensure you have plenty of suncream on.  I ended up catching the sun a bit even though I was wearing factor 50.  A breakfast box consisting of an omelette roll, muffin and small pastry was provided, along with a bottle of water.  There are also snacks brought round during the trip. Even on a calm day (we went out on a calm day) the sea can be quite rough and particularly at the front of the boat you may experience a lot of rocking about.  I'm an experienced whale watcher and rarely get seasick, but even I felt slightly queasy at one point.  I'm afraid a few passengers clearly did suffer, and they were very well looked after by the crew. The boat wasn't overfull and the crew were good at spotting whales, and clever at knowing where they'd resurface.  They helped us by pointing out where the whales were, with crew on both decks to do this.  There isn't a commentary or a marine biologist on board, as you get with some trips, but the staff were knowledgeable if asked questions. The trip can be quite long - generally it will last from 2-7 hours, depending on how quickly blue whales are found.  So that can mean a long time on the boat.  Small children may well not enjoy the experience, as it's a long time sitting around without much to do and not much to see, no matter how wonderful it is to see a whale for a small percentage of it.  I always suggest whale watching is best appreciated by children aged 8 and up, depending on the child of course. I would definitely recommend this trip to those who like wildlife.  You've got a good chance of seeing something, even if it's not a blue whale, if you go in season, and it's a reasonable company that provides a good experience.  Do take your seasickness remedy if you suffer though, and stay at the back of the boat which tends to be more stable.

We were a group of 17 adults and 16 kids booked to go for the whale watching, however, at the last moment half of the group have decided not to go, by the time we reached the boat we found no place to sit at all, keeping in mind that we are half the group only, with kids and infants. the boat crew are very rude, and not professional, also, they over load the boat with at least double the boat capacity. It is not recommended at all, unless you are desperate to see the whale. Moreover, most of the people on board the boat vomited several times, and we have seen the whale for only couple of seconds and that is it.

I imagine that if you are lucky and see lots of whales, this must be an amazing experience. Unfortunately we were not so lucky. We got up at 5 in the morning, drove for an hour, and then spent 7 hours on a boat packed with other tourists and all we saw was a few dolphins and a glimpse of a blue whale. So it felt like a lot of time and effort for nothing.
If you're lucky....you'll get to see the biggest 'mammal' on earth....We did...indescribable!!! We went with a smaller boat, Ragia & friends....

Its a must see visit but prepare for the rough sea and sea sickness. We started at 8 am and it took over an hour to go to the area where the whales are expected. We were lucky to be able to see one Orca n one Blue whale at a reasonable distance but only after almost 2 hours at sea. In fact, all the boats go to the same area and its really luck to be able to have a whale surface nearby. It may not be the best season as the sighting was not much with one whale a day as recorded on the sighting board. Quite a few passengers got sea sickness and it was not a real rough day. Having said that, its still a worthwhile trip

1.5 hours straight into ocean. you can see turtles, dolphins and ofcourse the giant blue whales. Its a ones a life time experience. We are lucky enough to be greeted by mating turtles, then whale gave us some great shots and on the return journey 100s of dolphines jumping around. pack you bags, and go go go.

We went to MIrrissa harbour at about 6.30 a.m and luckily we booked a boat of our friend for some cheaper price. Some people pay lot (like Rs 6000 per person) and some boats were so crowded. But in our case boat was not crowded and have enough space. We left the harbour at 7.15 am like and traveled about 2 hours straight. All the boats gather to same place.Usually I am not a vomiting person but this trip make me dizzy and uncomfortable due to boat's vibration. I think large boats like the Navy boat will be more stable than smaller boats.Few of passengers even vomited. May be situation would be better if we took the tablet boat staff gave. We got morning tea/coffee,some fruits, water bottle,drinks/milo and some buns. We saw few whales (one very near by) and some flying fish. We didn't see any dolphins.But I am not very satisfied with what I saw as I expected more. (I think luck matters !)  When there is a sign of a whale every boat tries to rush towards them making animal fierce. So I think these people should have some discipline rather than threatening whale habitat. Most of the people went with me were not happy about the journey.So if you are not a person who loves sea journeys or a person with sea sickness please avoid this. We were somewhat lucky and came back to shore at about 12pm-1pm but day before they have come at about 3pm which may be really tired.So better you take some food and drinks with you.

Yes, you are likely to see blue whales and other cetaceans but in order to do so you will be contributing to an unregulated free-for-all in which maybe 20 boats, each crammed to the gunnels with tourists, chase and harry any visible whale mercilessly. The whales clearly try to escape their pursuers. It's not a pretty sight. On our trip most of the fellow voyagers were Chinese tourists most of whom spent the entire trip prostrate and/or vomiting and/or playing their electronic games.

We signed up for this boat trip with the info that it will last 3,5-4 hours. In the ned it last almost 8 hours as it was hard to find the whales and we had a money back guarantee, which sounded good, but 8 hours was too long. We did see 3 whales in the end before they let us off the boat.... Not sure I would go again..... of course the boat was overloaded , no comfortable seat available for all passangers...
Absolutely awful. They argue with the coastguard because the boat is overloaded. The life jackets do not meet minimum SOLAS standards.

Overall the experience of our whale watching trip was an extreme waste of money, our hotel charged us 6000 Rupees which was after learning a ridiculous price. There are at least 15-20 boats going out each morning and literally harassing these whales out of their natural habitat, it makes me very angry that I ever did this!! If you truly respect this truly magical animal, watch a David Attenborough documentary about it, you'll see more of the whale and learn a whole lot more than sitting in a boat with no information and hardly any sighting. I do not condone the activity of chasing whales out of their homes and I regret ever doing it

We hired a private driver during our 2 week holiday in Colombo, It's much cheaper and more reliable than local taxi or hotel transport. Our day started at 3am, it took under two hours to get to the port from our hotel (The Kingsbury), once we arrived we were ushered out towards our boat, which to our surprise was already full, We were seated on the bottom deck, it costs roughly 5000 Sri Lanka rupees per person depending on who you book with (it includes a sandwich and water/juice) I suggest to take your own water,  snacks in a back pack)The whole experience lasts about 3-4 hours and it is worth every minute, we where incredibly lucky, we got to see at least 12 whales in action,there are also Dolphins but we did not see them,  Have your camera ready and be careful because a lot of people will push and shove, make sure you wear sun protection/hat/sunglasses as it gets extremely hot and if your trying to take pictures and make videos you will get burnt! It's a magical experience and you will literally be in awe of these magnificent creatures... We were fortunate with our driver and used him to do all the tourist haunts.

These are not whale watching trips at all. Just a glorified boat trip. If a whale is spotted, all the boats arrive and frighten the whales . Boats were far too close, no respect given to these lovely creatures, please leave them alone

I did a whale whatching tour and saw many blue whale, spinner Dolphins and even mating sea turtles (olive ridley). It was great but the only negative point was that it really was a safari, almost boats "fighting" with each other for the best spot... For the best price you best can go to the harbor your self, better than booking something.. My tour was around 4000 SL roepie.

Check to make sure you are in the whale watching season (October - April). We were there near the end and it took al long time for the boats to find whales. But we did get to see a few whales and for a good time. So, that's why I rate this attraction is "very good". But you have to be lucky to spot whales/dolphines.

We all had life jackets and individual seats on the boat. Everyone was offered sea sickness tablets before setting off if needed. We took ours when we left hotel. It was very choppy but we saw two schools of dolphins and four blue whales we were exited to see these as we understand they are wild and in their own environment so it's still a chance to see them no guarantee. We were issued breakfast and water when we set off and then on the way back a snack the staff were good to see who was getting a chance to see the whales and who wasn't and they did their best to man over people to be able to see the whale at least once. It was a good morning out.

We went there without booking and went until the end of the port (sea side) and enjoyed the trip with SayuriBoat. Boat was "human side" and ensuring not to stress/endanger whales. We managed to see whales and a wild bunch of dolphins. We want to inform that other companies with a big boat are NOT respecting distances, speed... to see animals in proper conditions for them. We had such bad experience with Sashimi boats which behave in a dangerous ways (speed, distance, overpacked) for passengers as well as for the animals. (attached picture)

We managed to see around 10 pods of Dolphins (spinners - performing tricks and responding to the whistles of the crew) and 3 blue whales who surfaced at least 10 times -and we saw the dive with full tail out of the water 3 times. Spectacular and well worth the bumpy ride out. The return was calmer - I agree with the reviewer who says if you are seasick or scared of totally open water this is not for you. My only concern was the way the various whale watching boats roared into action and headed for the poor whales the minute they surfaced.  Whether or not it does cause them fear or discomfort I don't know but it gave me an ill at ease feeling.

Our stay in Mirissa was marred by being forcibly packed into an already overcrowded boat-there were already people sitting on the deck through lack of seats.Do no be forced to buy tickets from the main advertised scam you might regret it !! Wait until you get to the harbour and choose for yourself  - there are lots of boats.The other minus was the amount of litter everywhere which will put us off returning to what is a lovely part of the beach with great restaurants

I counted 20 boots on the water chasing ascending whales. As soon as a whale breath was seen, the boats started to go in this directions. If you were on a slow and big boot, as we were, one arrived at this position after the whales have started to descent. Small and fast boots arrived there much faster. After a while the boots distributed and our boot started to predict the ascent of the whales which was successful. At the endd we have seen some fins, backs and breathes. Even if I like to spot and watch animals this tour was boring and the overall impression of chasing the whales we didn't like. For the whales sake, your time and what you see on this tour, I would not recommend to do it. After we arrive in Mirissa we got to know  that one can also snorkel with the whales, although it is pretty expensive (500 US dollar), it might be a super experience, because one can also see the dimensions of the whales. These tours take place during midday or afternoon when the whale watching boots have already left.

A little FYI: If you get sea-sick or afraid of deep water, then I guess, this won't be for you.. and have higher tendency of getting bad headaches or migraines. please bring your meds and sunglasses!! :) Sun block lotion also a good idea. We came to Mirissa by 5:45am as this journey requires an early start for a better chance of success and be on the first boat to sight the whales and boy, we did got lucky!! contact one of the boat guys and you can get yourself an early booking because you can't guarantee for a walk-in. Boats will provide you a soup, sandwiches, fish buns, tea and water bottles and biscuits, but it's wise to take couple of water bottles with you--just in case. We went to close to Sri Lankan ocean border limits before we sight our first whale and it was amazing!! Specially after meeting only few flying fish and other small fish for over 2hours! We were the first boat to find him, so we got have a nice clean look at him before other 4 boats joined us. and we got lucky again twice! the third whale sight, well that one, i dont think even the boat guys saw him coming.. whale was so close, we got even scared that the boat might even flip off.. it was scary but fun exciting experience and i would love to have it again!! :) On our way back to land, we met 3 pods of dolphins too!! if i am not mistaken, they belonged to two different types of dolphins. of course in Mirissa you wont meet those classic beautiful dolphins. Say a little prayer and try it out, course sometimes, you don't whales at all even you send 8hours looking for them. An experience i would not regret and one ticked off from my bucket list O:)

If you go to Galle in Sri Lanka, make sure that you drive 1 hour to Mirissa to go whale watching with this company. We make a private boat trip and service was excellent. We saw 5 whales and many dolphins. They render an excellent service!!!

I wanted to initially go with the whale watching club as I read awesome reviews about it. Waste of time and money really.  Definitely depends luck.  Did get to see whales but only the backs of them and only a couple that spouted.  Lots of dolphins but then you can see them anywhere. No guarantees on how much you get to see, we got a few glimpses of their backs. Still worth it. Crew is very nice, helpful and kind. They ensure everyone has had a fair chance to see before they turn around.

Ok, we didn't see whales, but we knew that might happen - october is not a good time for whale whatching and we were fully awared that. we got to see whales 3 times and once dolphins. Go with whale watching club It was a nice experience. I went there with my kids aged 5 and 9. Some people may get sea sick.

Mirissa is probably one  of the best place to see blue whales in the world. It is also very good place to see few species of dolphins such as spinners and bottle nose. Also there is a very good chance to see sperm whales, Brite whales with a bit of luck and experience guidens

Mirissa is one of best place to watch the whales. We did this in January. Couple of points to note: 1. There are a lot of service providers for this service. No matter which one you chose, tourists are grouped in a common boat from Mirissa. Standard rates at 6000 LKR(unless you want a private boat) 2. Time: December to April is the time when whales migrate to this place. 3. You should start around 6 in the morning from your hotel so as to reach the docks by 6:30. 4. Breakfast & sea sickness pills are provided by the Whale watching association at the boat. If someone feels sea sick, you can still raise an emergency and someone will pick you up in the sea and take back. We saw 7-8 whales, many Dolphins & sea turtles as well.

Best place to see live whales and dolphin's.we been guided by Shafith,such a beautiful things we watched there.shafith is tour guide and driver who knows the best time to see those things.if any one who needs him please contact +94775004241

I stayed at Mirissa for 3 nights and booked this trip through the hotel. It cost me Srilankan Rupees 4,000. You have to be at the peer by 7.00 am. My hotel dropped me there in a three wheeler taxi for free. The boat was a double decker one carrying over 50 persons. Most of the passangers were young Chinese. First we were asked to wear life jackets and given tablets for sea sickness. Thereafter a simple breakfast of sandwiches was served. The motor driven boat travelled about 30 kms into deep sea. It has sophisticated sonar devices linked to GPS to detect where the whales are. When a whale is identified under the sea, the ship will travel to that spot and switch off the engine and wait till the whale surfaces. Every 15 minutes the whale has to come to the surface to breathe in. When the whale surfaces, it will first exhale which creates a water geyser about 3 metres tall. Then the whale will breathe in and remain on the surface for about 10 seconds and go to the bottom of the sea. It is a remarkable experience. Altogether we saw 6 whales on this day. The shipping company gives a written guarantee that if we did not see a single whale, they will take us next day for free. The whale watching trips are available 7 days a week. Mirissa is located in the Southern Province of Srilanka not far from the town of Matara. This is a very exhilarating experience and I can recommend it to anyone visiting Srilanka anytime in the year. The cost is quite reasonable by Western standards. I consider the boats are quite safe. They are regularly inspected by the Srilankan Coast Guard Department.

Mirissa is the great place for whale watching. And the blue whales are just majestic. Largest of the world. Also good boats available in Mirissa. We had a trip organised through our hotel Sea Goggle for very reasonable price like 3000 rupee. With breakfast served on the boat.good people in the boat too

if u bargain a lot , it can go down to 2500 rp instead of the 50usd that many companies ask online Most of them will give u a second try for free if you dont see anything i tried 2 times and just saw dolphins... but at least i paid just once

There were about 60 pax on board the ship and by the timwe we wwere due to return to the harbour, about 40 of them were filling the bags provided. It was actually quite humorous - not for those with the nose bags though!! The whale season is later in the year and the seas were quite rough. Worst experience during my whole travel through Sri Lanka... there were something like 12 very noisy boats full of tourists which were chasing one poor whale... we were ashamed that we took part in something like that, don't recomend to those who want to experience something deeper than just taking pics of whales tail and share then on fb, it's strictly touristic, those who don't like crowds and who actually care about our enviroment should spend money on sth different!
The ride lasts for a couple of hours and we got to see several whales. They didn't exactly jump up and smile for the cameras but it was still cool to be so close to some of the biggest animals on

We stayed at Bentota and opted for whale watching at Mirissa which is at a 90 minutes drive from Bentota towards the southern most tip of Sri Lanka. We managed to sight 3 whales and it was great to experience it.
A blue whale is gigantic. To witness such a large and clumpsy but at the same time graceful and magnificant is a memory I will keep for the rest of my life. No matter the price, it is worth it.

Mirissa we visited in February 2015, and I agreed whale watch trip with Whale watching in Mirissa club. The trip was wonderful, we saw many whales, turtles and dolphins. Our captain and owner of the ship Rangan Manoj wanted to show us as much as possible. On the trip we were 6 hours. I could even drive a boat while. The ship's crew are looked after us the whole way. It was wonderful. It was for us one of the strongest experiences in Sri Lanka!

This was one of the finest experience of my life. Managed to see 7 Whales and more than 100 Dolphins swimming around our boat. If ever anyone visits Sri Lanka, this is a must see place. Regards, Viral

I did this tour on a cloudy and windy day when the sea was very rough and almost 90% of all passengers on board vomited and got sick. It was a 4 hour trip and I saw about 6 whales. It was not possible to take photos as in most times you see the geyser of water and sometimes fins and tails. The overall thrill was good and I enjoyed the experience. The crew were very helpful and obliging.

I was convinced by my driver to go on the whale watching trip. After having casually confirmed to the driver I tried to cancel the trip because it started too early but I was told that there wasn't any refund(even though no payment was made). Therefore, I was forced to take this trip. The trip was supposed to be for 4 hours in total but the crew were determined to find whales and dolphins and didn't want to return until they found one. I should had made more sense after reading the line at the ticket sales office "if you don't see the whales or Dolphins, you can take the trip for free again tomorrow". After sailing continuously for over 4 hour in one direction I simply couldn't accept the fact that they wouldn't stop and would keep going deeper. I got sea sick(at least 5 other people on the boat got sea sick too) which I have never been before and I was forced to approach the captain to turn around but he refused to. I then offered the captain to pay whatever it takes to get a speedboat and take me back to land. They charged me 300 usd to take me back. The speedboat took 1 hour to reach me and was very small but I had no choice. I boarded the small speed boat even though I had huge safety concerns but boarded it anyway as I had life jacket on and had no other choice. It took us 45 minutes to get back to land and on the way the speedboat almost turned upside down three times. To conclude, this has been the worst excursion of my life and I do not suggest anyone to take this excursion unless they are fine with spending countless hours at sea in choppy waters.

This is one of the best places in Sri Lanka you will get to see whales and dolphins. The tour operator booked us the hotel and arranged for whale watching trip. It was really an experience. Not only one will get to see whales but also some dolphins. It will cost only around $50. So don't miss it but you need to visit the country during the whaling season - between early December and late March.

Our trip was booked through our hotel but on arrival there looked to be loads of providers so I wish we had just booked the transport and then negotiated a price for the trip ourselves. There looked to be better boats than the one we were on but we weren't cramped which was good. I also saw a boat with a guide talking to the customers but only the one. We were given a nice breakfast on board and managed to get a seat at the front. After the first couple of hours we were starting to think that the trip was a bust but then we caught sight of a blue whale . Once they knew where they were we saw five! No Dolphins though. We were further away than I excepted but we did get some good pics. I also a bit concerned by the amount of boats that gathered around. It was almost like the whales were being herded once they spotted them but they did stay a reasonable distance away it was a great experience as we saw the whales but I can understand the people who have been disappointed by lack of sightings

This sounded like a worthwhile outing to do except maybe not with a 2 and 5 year olds in tow. We were told it was a 4 hour outing, when in fact, we left our hotel at 7am and returned at 2pm. The boat was packed with approx. 70 people on board x 5 boats all around. The snacks promised were disappointing. We never saw a whale and only a small pod of dolphins. The dolphins were exciting but the whole trip was way too long and difficult to handle with young kids in tow.

We saw many whales but unfortunately we didnt see any dolphines. The guide on the boat was very caring and did everything to make us happy. I even took a swim in the ocean from the boat. I recommend this trip!!

to many boats chasing the whales. We only saw to tails of the whales,while they we're submerging. I cant blame them, being chased down by 30 boats. There where a few moments when they thought they spotted one. but we just ended up with all the boats around a turtle. Who was probably thinking "what is this all about???"

It was an amazing journey!  We came to Mirissa harbour at early morning about 7am, found a big boat, which we liked and we did not wait too much from this trip. But after 40 minutes in the ocean we saw a first fountain, after that we came closer to the whales and started to chase them. We saw their backs and tails and all in all we counted about 20 different whales. After 1 hour we tired of watching and chasing and were ready to go back, but the captain turned out boat to dolphin watching and we have seen about 100 or more of this funny creatures, they were jumping and diving around our boat! Finally about 10 am we came back to the harbour and went at home. Great boat and great captain, we could totally suggest this boat (Mirissa Whale watching club) for this kind of experience!

The sea is rough, so is not recommended for anyone who gets sea sick. That said, we were fortunate enough to see 3 blue whales and also lots of dolphins. It is expensive at $50 per person. All the boats go out together, and all follow the whales together, so it doesn't matter what boat you go out in.

If you are a beach lover, you have to add this place in your "must go" bucket list.  The water is so cleaned and clear, some parts are calm, good for snorkeling and swimming, fishing, some parts are waving, good for surfer.  Many sea creatures can be seen here for example like coral fishes, sea turtles, sea urchins, corals and etc....It's a two hours drive from the Colombo airport to the Mirissa beach, advanced hotel reservation is needed during high season, otherwise, you may need to stay in a poor dorm.  Easy to travel around the area by tuk tuk.

This trip, no matter who use use, is just a trip where whales are chased.  If one boat sees a whale, all other 30 or so boats go tearing to the area as well.  By the time the boats arrive the whale have either traveled further, or possible even run over, I don't know.  But it was not a respectful way to treat the animals in any case.  Any true nature/animal lover would not appreciate the way these tours are conducted.

wildlife watching is a gamble and whale watching even more so. This gamble failed but more on other factors than the wildlife. The trip was expensive at 8000R. The boat was large but very full, every seat taken including those with a metal pole directly in front. A couple next to us with a young child were told to put her on their lap so the seat could be freed up. The whales were obviously otherwise engaged as it was probably 3 hours before we got a distant sighting. Because of this when the whale was spotted everyone poured onto one side and the boat tilted alarmingly. The crew were shouting at people to go onto the opposite side but not to great effect. This was quite scary as they weren't in control and the mob wanted to see their whale. Over the next 2 hours we "chased " this whale and saw it twice again, although only brief glimpses. The sea was quite choppy and a lot of people were sick. There was no information supplied over a PA, or any written info which could have entertained us even if no whales were spotted. Due to the lack of whales the trip was 6 hours, it was rough it was very hot and regularly sprayed with sea water . To be honest it was a great endurance. I accept that it's not the owners fault on the lack of whales, but the others factors made it so much worse. Be aware we were advised by our tour leader that they use this boat as its " the best"

We were offered 3 options for trip from 2500-6000pp. We got the middle 3500 but in hindsight you could have probably gone for the cheapest - the boats all follow each other. Had a hairy start when our captain sailed too fast out of the harbour, nearly hitting a fisherman on a tiny boat and then smashing (& I'm not exaggerating with the use of the word) into another boat. Luckily all damage was well above water line so we got back to harbour and they swapped us onto a new ship (with new captain thank goodness) The trip itself was a success with the sight of at least 4 blue whales, majestic and huge. We saw mating turtles and pods of dolphins. Amazing!

We went whale watching with the boat from Paradise Beach hotel, wich is rather big compaired with the others. We had a breakfast on board, wich was given in a plastick bag. We did not get any information about whales or dolphins, like I heard, Raja does. But it was a ver special experience to see those beautiful creatures rise up  out of the sea! However it is a bit sad, when they show up, all those boats rush in to them!

All the boats go out together, and all follow the whales together, so it doesn't matter what boat you go out in although the bigger ones may keep you out slightly longer. We saw the wales though, brillient

Me and my family had the best excursion ever in Sri Lanka with the team of guides on board the Sea liner. They were very friendly and welcoming. I fell that the money they charge to do this tour is expensive, I never thought that the sea would be that rough and never at any point where we advised that if I was pregnant not to go on the trip, I'm very comfortable on boats however this was by far the most roughest scariest ride to the point I apologised to my young son for taking him on the trip as he was petrified. I feel that there should be age restrictions to maybe aged 10 upwards and also health question should be implemented to assertion ones health as I feel that pregnant women should not be allowed to do this trip either as I also feared for my unborn child

A very attentive owner and we saw 3 very large whales close to the boat. Small boat so everyone had a place on the rails. on the day. No guarantees but a good chance. We need a new model that preserves local income, but protects the whales.
Left the hotel at 4am to see the whales.  Whilst we did see 5 or 6 from a distance, I felt the whales were chased by the boats and were being harassed so that people could take photos of them

The Blue Whale is the largest creature ever to have lived on Earth. Only recently have people become aware that The Southern tip of Sri Lanka is one of the best spots to see this magnificent mammal. Well worth a detour to Mirrissa, despite the many boats.  But note you must go with a reputable operator, so they keep their distance and don't harass the whales.

I think I would not repeat that trip again: We spent 5,5h on a shaky not very comfortable boat with 40 other people, many of which got seasick despite the pills that were handed out. After the sightings we had to drive back for almost 3 hours. If you're keen anyhow, bring one of those neck pillows from the airplane. This way you might manage to doze off a bit despite the hard unfomfortable plastic chairs. And in case you decide to do  this with children...bring food and a lot of games or devices.

Unfortunately we went on a rainy day- not a good idea. Besides the swell it is difficult to see marine mammals in these conditions as a grey sky and chopping water makes for limited visibility. Furthermore the boats are jammed packed so you could end up like we did on the top deck, completely wet and cold and sea-sick for a 7 hour boat ride.

We set off at 7am on a boat for 'whale watching'. The boat was open to the elements and I spent the whole of the journey back to shore with a life jacket proped over my face to try and shelter myself from the rain. The seats were rock hard also so to spend 8 hours aboard this boat was a nightmare not a pleasure. The food was below average and they even handed out all the vegetarian meals to the non vegetarians. For the money ¬£60 for two of us it was terrible value. Oh and as for the whale, it was a grey whale, which is a lot smaller than the promised blue whale. And they spend about 20 minutes chasing the poor things once they had spotted it just to appease some of the less discerning tourists on the boat. Seriously avoid this one and spend a day doing something fun!

Overpriced, and on most days - you blink and you've missed it. Dolphins yes, on most occasions they are there, but whales - most probably no.
First trying to find whales, and then seeing the spout of water, followed by the whole whale, then they flip their tales as they dive....

I had booked earlier through email and had bargained for LKR 4000 per person but it looks like LKR 2500 is the lowest. Although LKR 4000 is still acceptable if we end up having a good time. We were expecting a pickup from our hotel as promised but no one showed up. We were helped by Prasad from Bon Accord to finally get a ride to the harbor. We paid and were shown the way to the boat through the extremely smelly fish market area in the harbor. On board the speedboat, we were provided black coffee. The trip started and we had to travel a few hours into sea before spotting anything. First we spotted some few hundred dolphins playing in an area. After some time we proceeded further and spotted 2 blue whales. The water spray through sprout is the most visible followed by tail lash before they deep die. We saw few more whales before we proceeded back. Tour started at 7 and ended around 10-20am. We were provided water bottles, mixed fruit packed juice and a tuna sandwich (which we refused as we were vegetarians). Overall a good trip.

Well its defn, worth it awesome dolphins flying fish worth the heat and tan under sun well boats are pretty safe and they are in pacs of 8 - 10 well spaced trust me whale and the boa drivers are both scared of each other. However the political senario in the harbour is poor company people fighting with each other for customers we had one guys run down to us and shout on our face asking how much were we charged h claimed to be a govt. guy but then he had no id card and was smelling of alcohol. so beer through all of this to see the whales

All boats leave at 7am from the harbor and they sail about 500m apart until they spot a whale when the chase starts. Fun experience, don't pay more than 2500 rupies per person. Official price is 6000, most people pay about 4000, but lowest is 2500. On speedliner you get a sendwich, juice and water, staff is friendly. We saw some whales.

Its simply adventurous...and the experience one has is simply out of this world. Since I did not visit at the peak time so had to spend more time going further into the sea. The blue whales are found...not one or two...but many...and the sight of release of fountain of water by a whale makes the experience a memorable one..but simply not a place for visit by kids and above all....no connectivity...it WATER WATER EVERYWHERE!!!

We booked a 3-5 hour whale watching tour.  Honestly it was the worst boat experience I have ever had.  The day started with the company forgetting to pick us up until my husband called.  When we arrived at the harbor my husband asked if it was safe as it was raining and the water was rough.  We were told no problem.  We paid the guide upon arrival and of course he didn't have change.  The change was a minimal amount and he promised to give it to us upon return.  This never happened.  90 percent of the guests became seasick within an hour of departure.  At 3 hrs into the trip no whales were spotted and guests were so sick they were laying on the floor of the boat.  At 4 hrs in guests were requesting to return to harbor.  Staff lied and told us we were returning and would be back in an hour.  At 6 hrs in it was like mutiny on the bounty and the captain was still searching for a whale.  The swells were so high I got drenched.  Small kids were so sick and guests requests to return.  We left harbor at 7am and did not get back until 330pm.  My husband and I do not get seasick and felt disgusted that this company was so unresponsive and ignorant to the safety of its passengers.

it was more than we ever imagined. we were bit skeptical weather we see any at all.... but we saw lot of them....plus hundreds of dolphins too.. you have to wait for the right seasons as whales worn t be there year long. but seeing such massive creatures so close is an experience of a life time... no words to explain!!!

I always use trip advisor but have never been as moved to make a review as I have after today's experience. This company was chaotic at best but in reality could seriously have injured the people on board. In short, the boat was completely full with not a seat to spare, something that must have caught the disorganised staff by surprise as they rushed to get extra life jackets from a neighbouring vessel prior to our departure. The weather was quite bad today and the journey was very bumpy to say the least (not their fault) and over half of the people in the downstairs deck vomited (again, not their fault). After around 3 or 4 hours of sailing without seeing any whales (again, not their fault) they asked who would like to continue looking for whales for several more hours. As the majority of people (or at least their children / partners / friends) had been vomiting for hours at this point, most people wanted to go back to Mirissa, although some were keen to continue searching. As a 'solution' to the fact that some people wanted to stay out at sea, the team hailed down another boat that was heading back to shore and attempted to move those who didn't want to stay over to this boat. People were rushed to jump over to the other boat, without life jackets, whilst the two boats were unsecured and banging against each other in rough waters. We were 15 miles from shore, this was extremely dangerous and if someone had fallen and been caught between the two boats this could have proven fatal. We had to shout out to stop what was happening and the only vocalised concern of the staff was that we were not getting a refund. As the sea is not a zoo, we didn't expect to see whales during this trip, and were more concerned about the welfare of our fellow passengers, some of whom had been vomiting for hours and were weak and unwell. Afterwards we were thanked by very many people on board who had been terrified of being pressurised into jumping between boats but were too scared to speak out. Again, the staff reiterated that we were not getting a refund. The money was the furthest things from our mind at this point. We subsequently went back to shore and were more than pleased to reach dry land. In all my years of travelling I have never seen the safety of tourists so disregarded as I did today. Do not travel with this company. They operate using the email whalewatchingmirissa@gmail.com, the manager is called Ganidu Rochana and they also refer to themselves as Speedliner.

If you are a wildlife enthusiast and looking for an experience that you may not forget for the rest of your life, then Whale watching surely fits the bill .. and Sri Lanka is a great place to go whale watching. Whales are found in the Indian Ocean and hence you need to head to the southern part of Sri Lanka. One of the most poplular spots for whale watching is Mirissa -  located on the western coast of Sri Lanka, this place is about 170-180 kms South of Colombo.  The Whale spotting trip (safari) is an early morning affair and the boats leave around 6.30. It is not possible to cover this from colombo and it is advisable that you plan your stay either in Mirissa, or at Galle ( 20kms from Mirissa) or Hikkaduwa (45kms from Mirissa) or Bentota (70kms from Mirissa) ...  all these places are in one line and south of colombo along the costal route.  We had made Hikkaduwa as our base and travelled to Mirissa which took us about 50 minutes as the roads are narrow and there are several small villages and towns alongside and hence there is a fair amount of traffic early in the morning. The best way to do this trip is to book with one of the tour operators in advance.  You may need to make a payment at the time of booking or some of them are even open to accepting payments just before the start of the trip.  We were a family of two adults and child and travelling from India - we opted for a company called "Whale Watching Mirissa" and the owner is Ganidu Rochana.  We went with Rochana basis the reviews from travellers who had engaged his services - the decider for us was the service standards maintained by him and the understanding of his staff on the subject. And we were not wrong.  It is also important to be sure of the fact that the operator is engaging big size boats - as the trip extends into the deep seas, a big boat is far more stable.  The rates could vary from operator to operator and could range from 9000 Sri Lanka Rupees to 17000 SLR  -  it is advisable to fix the rates at the time of doing the bookings. Most of the boats leave Mirissa around 6.30 am - there are some clearances required, but a good operator takes care of all these procedures.   The entire trip could be a 4-5 hour trip and is certainly not for people who have sea sickness.  For those who haven't ventured into the sea and hence are not sure if they have sea sickness or not, it is advisable to take precautions - the trip is a tough one and a long trip.  It is a advisable to take the medicines for sea sickness an hour before the start of the trip.  Also make sure to carry your glares and camera with zoom lens - the whales will be at a distance and a normal camara is of no use.   Most of the boats have a lower and an upper deck. The view from the upper deck is certainly better and offers better angles for photography. You could read more about the experience on the blog .. http://wowplaces.blogspot.in/2014/01/whale-watching-in-sri-lanka-experience.html?view=magazine A final word, during the trip, make sure you drink enough water - as the heat and the humidity could sap you.   Go ahead, and enjoy this spectacular experience.

The chance to see a Blue Whale was one of the major reasons we chose to go to Sri Lanka & we were not disappointed! We contacted Ganidu Rochana from Whale Watching Mirissa before we left home and he kept in touch with us via email & text right up until the day of our trip. He even arranged transport from our hotel, around 2 hours away from Mirissa, which was an air conditioned vehicle with a very friendly driver. Arriving at the harbour around 6:30am you see masses of local fishermen selling their catch. Ganidu was there to meet us and accept our payment. As we arrived the crew were making sure that the boat was clean, including the toilet. We headed straight up onto the observation deck and positioned ourselves at the front on one of the mats provided. There is a small roof, but take sun cream, it may not feel too hot but you are out at sea for around 5 hours. A tasty breakfast was served, although we decided not to eat until after we got back to dry land. The sea is pretty choppy so we took a couple of sea sickness tablets just to make sure that nothing could ruin our trip. We were only about 10-15 minutes out of the harbour when up popped a Right Whale. Continuing further out to sea there was almost constant communication between all the whale watching boats to give you the best chance of seeing something. After a few more Right whales, the odd Green Turtle and a Ray fish we finally got to see our first Blue Whale. The crew are fantastic at spotting the whales and quickly point out the "spray" when the whale breathes out and moments after this the top of the whale glides out of the water. They also have great respect for the whales keeping the distance as per the regulations, unfortunately not all the boats follow these rules and end up scaring the whale into the depths. We enjoyed our whale watching trip so much we went again and this time the Blue Whales treated us to a show of their tales, a truly awesome sight.
