I thought they were some sort of experts who could maybe tell you about the whales and knew roughly where to pinpoint them, but actually the crew are the equivalent of boy racers of the ocean who nail it around at top speed hoping to find something, and there is no guarantee that you will. The rate for this godawful experience is beyond a rip-off when you look at what you have been spending on food and accommodation. I didn't think I suffered from sea-sickness, but by the end all but two of the passengers were gripping to the rails trying not to be sick (with mixed success). My girlfriend described it as the worst experience of her life and said she wanted to jump in the ocean to make the nausea stop. I wouldn't go quite as far as this but it is definitely not an experience I would recommend or repeat.

We set off very early in the morning on Boxingday having had no sleep due to the beach partys. The boats all left more or less together and we quickly saw a few whales in the distance.After a rather basic breakfast we set off for deeper water to see Blue whale however they decided not to join us as is the way with wild animals.The sea was fairly flat but almost everyone except us got sea sick with one American demanding to be taken back to port. Prices for this trip range from R3,000-R7,000 for the same trip so shop around.

They are not the cheapest, however I think they are the best. On the day we went out they could not find whales for a long time. The other boats that had been close alongside turned back about 30 minutes before us, having seen a few whales at a distance. We were finally rewarded by close views including the classic dive with the tail in the air. We also saw dolphins on the way back and, in spite of the fact we were going to arrive back about an hour later than expected they happily stopped for us to enjoy watching the dolphins' antics - including jumping up and swimming close to the boat. I got the strong impression that the crew really tried their hardest and went the extra distance to make saw we saw the whales properly.

Encountered blue whale, the largest animal in the world at the open water outside Mirissa habor.  We witnessed two blue whales surfaced and stayed close to our boat. They were much bigger than the boat. It was so amazing.  A must do thing if you are going to Sri Lanka between Nov - Apr.

Left port with great expectations in company of several other boats. No briefing from staff. Only 30 second sightings x 4 on full morning trip, however sea calm. Not thrilling. Cost about 50 euros so too expensive I think. Breakfast couldn't have been more basic. I wouldn't bother.....

I would strongly recommend this as a half day option getting away from the beach.  The sea South of Mirissa has great wildlife and there is a very high chance of seeing Blue Whales and also large numbers of Spinner Dolphins.  We also saw a sea snake, although that is a rare sighting. There is some variation in the quality of boats that go out.  We went with the Mirissa Paradise Beach Hotel's outfit, which was very nice - decent quality modern trimaran with friendly crew (plenty of life jackets) and a half decent breakfast provided.  Price was SLR6,500 p.p.  Unlike the previous reviewer I found (at least this operator) to offer a service the equal of whale watch trips in the US or NZ.

Seeing blue whales out in the open ocean is an incredible sight, no doubt.  However, if you want to see blue whales off the Southern Sri Lankan coast, you probably need to minimise your expectations of the ease and comfort of such a trip, particularly if you have already seen whales off the Pacific Coast of Canada/USA or in Hawaii. The options available are either the largest available vessel operated by the Sri Lanka Navy and what can only be described as a ferry.  It is probably the most comfortable trip of the available boats, but the viewing platform is crowded and the size of the vessel means it is very difficult to manoeuvre close to the beautiful ocean mammals.  Prices for a morning trip are quoted at up to US$100pp for foreigners.  As usual in Sri Lanka I suspect Sri Lankan nationals pay less. At the other end of the scale, you can arrange a trip often through a tuk tuk driver for US$50-65pp on a much smaller boat.  Be warned however that the swell once you are out of Mirissa is frequently 4-5 feet and the boat we were on travelled at c. 11kph.  We were required to wear life jackets, but there was absolutely no briefing, safety or otherwise, from the skipper.  It was more of a taxi service than a guided tour.  Of the 25 tourists on our boat 5+ people were sea sick which took the gloss off the trip somewhat. On a very positive note however, the boats we saw once we got close to the whales did not attempt to harass or get to within less than 20m to the whales, which was quite a pleasant change from our nature trips I have been on. I would still recommend the trip but just be warned that it isn't cheap, those who suffer motion sickness will get likely be sick and it is a minimum 4 hour trip.  But then again how often do you get to see Blue Whales?

Our tuk tuk driver took us to the harbourside office that runs whale watching trips but in fact  Whale Watching Mirissa is a different operation and we had to communicate with the boat owner directly by mobile phone which was not easy given the language barrier.  The website is run from Colombo and I guess they contact the local boats to make arrangements as required.  This came as a bit of a surprise a to me! Our boat was small but we had it to ourselves and after over an hour's sailing out to sea, our vessel was actually the first one to sight a whale (quite a few boats set off at around the same time and split up) then every boat chases the whales for more sightings.  At times there were two whales in view at a time but because of the speed they move at and the distance they cover it was impossible to say how many whales we saw but it was an exciting hour spent whirling about and setting off in pursuit of the next spout of water or sight of a great black shape in the ocean.  The fare seemed good value at SLR50,000 especially as we were the only passengers on this occasion (they would have taken more if anyone else had turned up I'm sure) but I don't know how it compares with the "official" tour boat.  We didn't partake of the breakfast offered, it was quite a bumpy ride and my partner felt a bit seasick at times.  A true adventure can never be cosy!  We were however in safe hands with four crew members including an expert spotter. In future all we will remember will be the excitement of the 'chase' and the awe of seeing these magnificent creatures in their own environment.
